system.description:
[Foundry Note: A non-saving cast is provided for when the spell is cast upon an object.

The spell doesn't specify the change in strength for creatures without a book STR score, which is most "monstrous" NPCs.  A house rule effect that simply multiplies their damage by increasing percentage based on caster level is also provided, if the GM prefers to handle the spell consequences in that fashion- Ed.]

 

General

This spell causes a creature or object to grow in size and weight. The spell increases:

  •  a creature's size and weight by 20% per caster level (to a maximum increase of 200%)
  • an object's size and weight by 10% per caster level (to a maximum increase of 100%).

The magic user's power limits the volume of material that he or she can enlarge; the mage can affect no more than:

  • 10 cubic ft per level of living matter
  • 5 cubic ft per level of non-living matter

The reverse of this spell is Reduce.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If the spell is cast on an unwilling recipient, a successful saving throw will negate the spell, but willing recipients may choose to forgo the save.

 

Combat Effects

A normal sized person doubled in size will generally have strength of 18, and tripled in size would have strength of 20+.

actions.name: Enlarge
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (If cast on an actor) target an actor and click the  "Enlarge (MU L?-L?) - Duration (T)" action corresponding to the level of the caster
    • If the actor is a non-character monster without a STR score (e.g., a MU summons a goblin and then casts Enlarge on it) then use the   "Enlarged No STR Score - Duration (T)" action instead

system.description:
[Foundry Note: if the caster splits up multiple missiles between targets, apply the various damage ranges as missiles; i.e., if a caster has three missiles and sends two to Target A and one to Target B, apply the damage of 2d4+2 to Target A and 1d4+1 to Target B, etc.]

 

General

When this spell is cast, missiles of magical energy dart forth from the caster's fingertips, striking unerringly at his or her intended target(s), even if the target(s) are in melee or are partially concealed.

 

Combat Effects

The missiles inflict [[/roll 1d4+1]] points of damage each.

For every two caster levels beyond first, the caster gains an additional missile; thus, a first-level magic user can cast one missile, a third-level caster may cast 2, a fifth-level caster may cast 3, and so on.

actions.name: Magic Missile
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target an actor and click the  "Damage (? Missiles)" action corresponding to the number of missiles being sent against that actor
    • The caster can split up their total missiles between multiple targets, but will need to target actors and apply damage sequentially

system.areaOfEffect: 1+ creatures in a 10 ft x 10 ft area

system.description:
[Foundry Note: if the rolled bonus would take an actor with a STR rating over a score of 18, the intent is that all excess would apply to exceptional strength instead of increasing by whole numbers. 

So if cast upon a thief with a STR of 15, and rolling a "5", 3 points would take the thief up to 18 and the remaining 2 points would increase the thief's STR to 18.20, but not increase their STR to a score of 20. 

The GM will need to manually adjust "spillover" if the effect increases STR above 18, as there is no automation to recognize the condition and split the roll.

The 1d6 roll discussed below for non-classed actors is a manual roll by the caster; apply which of the two effects correlates with that roll result. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell increases a person's strength (affecting the same sorts of creatures as Hold Person).

 

REFERENCED TEXT:

Creatures affected by Hold Person include humans, demi-humans and humanoids. Ultimately, it is in the discretion of the GM to decide if a creature is considered a "person" for the purposes of this spell.

 

Combat Effects

The recipient's strength increases by [[/roll 1d6]], and members of the various fighter-type classes gain a roll of [[/roll 1d6+1]].

If the spell is cast upon a monster (such as an orc), the GM is free to rule for convenience that the effect of the spell is to grant +1 to damage, and if the [[/roll 1d6]] roll is a 5 or 6, a +1 to hit as well.

actions.name: Strength
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • Target the actor and click the action below which applies to their nature:
    • If cast on a fighter-type click the "Fighter Type STR Bonus - Duration (T)" action
    • If cast on any other classed actor click the "Non-Fighter STR Bonus - Duration (T)" action
    • If cast on a non-classed actor roll a die and (based on the result) apply either  "Monster Dmg Only - Duration (T)" or  "Monster Dmg+Atk - Duration (T)"

system.description:
General

The mirror image spell creates [[/roll 1d4]] phantasmal images of the magic user, all mirroring his or her actions. The spell's 6ft radius also becomes slightly blurred to sight, like the reflection of a slightly distorted mirror.

At the end of the spell's duration, any remaining images fade from sight.

The combination of these two magical phenomena makes it impossible to distinguish the images from the caster without aid of a magical nature, such as True Seeing.

 

Combat Effects

When an opponent makes a successful hit against one of the images, the image breaks up and disappears (the others remain). If an opponent attempts to attack a magic user obscured by this spell, it is randomly determined whether the to-hit roll is directed toward the person or one of the images.

actions.name: Mirror Image
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Mirror Image - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: unlike the illusionist version, which is a full radius and so is automated, the cone-shaped AOE of the MU version of this spell doesn't lend itself to an aura to show an AOE that moves with the caster. 

This makes using an automated detect invisibility effect impossible, as there's no way currently to make it only work in the beam-shaped area of effect that a magic user has.  

However, if there is ever a question of the AOE the caster can see at a given moment, the castshape effect can be superimposed on the map again temporarily to show the visual area without setting it down on the scene (right-click to dismiss).  Then the GM can ping where an invisible creature is for the MU player and provide a verbal description.

A "Sixth Sense (Scrying)" skill is provided on spellcasting actors having high levels, which is also modified by high INT.  Should this spell's use be attempted on any actor having this skill, a passive check to notice the scrying should be made every round. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell allows the caster to see that which is invisible or hidden, and also to perceive the astral and aethereal planes.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell's sight is limited to the stated area of effect of 10 ft/caster level.

actions.name: Detect Invisibility
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the "Detect Invisibility - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: there isn't currently a way to effect immunity to only normal missiles while deprecating magical items of these sorts.  An immunity effect to piercing would also negate damage from daggers and short swords, etc. 

The GM may however decline to roll damage for normal missiles while manually applying damage (minus 1) of magical versions of these weapons - Ed.]

 

General

The subject of this spell becomes completely invulnerable to the effects of projectiles.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell's power is not sufficient...to ward off the larger missiles hurled by siege engines such as catapults and ballistae, nor the enchantment of a magic arrow or bolt.

The spell conveys no protection whatsoever against spells, including spells with missile-like qualities such as Fireball or Ray of Enfeeblement.

 

Combat Effects

Any damage caused by weapons this spell is insufficient to ward off (as discussed above) is reduced by 1 hit point per die.

actions.name: Protection From Normal Missiles
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Prot. Normal Missiles- Duration (T)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: the GM will need to track halved number of attacks for slowed creatures manually, but four movement rate effects are provided which halve the common base move rates of 120, 90, 60, and 30, for the GM to selectively apply if applicable. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell acts upon its targets to slow down their movements.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell may be cast upon up to 1 creature/caster level, but all must be within the spell's area of effect at the time of casting.

Haste and Slow automatically cancel each other without any shocks to the systems of those affected.

 

Combat Effects

Any creature affected by a Slow spell will find that it can only move at half normal speed and attack at half its normal rate.

If more than one Slow spell is cast upon the same subject, the effects of the two spells will be cumulative.

actions.name: Slow
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target chosen actors in the AOE and click the  movement action corresponding to the actor's current movement rate

system.description:
General

With a pointing gesture at the ending of the incantation, the magic user causes a massive explosion of magical fire at the target point.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Creatures making successful saving throws suffer only half the indicated damage.  If they fail this saving throw their carried items are also at risk as described below.

The flames do not create any significant change in air pressure, but the furnace-like heat causes items in the blast not borne by someone making a personal saving throw, to make item saving throws against magical fire or ignite (or, in the case of metals, melt). 

 

Combat Effects

When the magic user casts the spell, a bead of light streaks from his or her pointed finger to the target area, and if it strikes another object directly in its path the fireball will detonate immediately.

The fireball detonates with a low roar, causing [[/roll 1d6]] damage per caster level to all creatures within the area of effect.

The blast fills the entire volume of the spell radius, and if it is cast into an enclosed area smaller than the area of effect the flames will expand from this area until the spell's full volume has been reached.

The volume of a 20 ft radius sphere is approximately 33,500 cubic ft, and there are 1,000 cubic ft in a 10 ft x 10 ft x 10 ft area, so in an area with a 10 ft ceiling the fireball will fill approximately thirty-three 10 ft x 10 ft squares.

Thus, if a fireball explodes in the middle of a corridor 10 ft wide and 10 ft high, the blast will extend a staggering 165 ft in both directions.

It is quite possible, particularly in dungeoneering environments, for the magic user to be caught in the backblast of his or her own Fireball spell.

actions.name: Fireball
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors in the AOE then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger a saving throw (this may already have been done)
  • Click the  "Damage (Fireball)" action

This spell enhances the magic user's precision of memory, allowing him or her to retain up to three additional spell levels in his or her mind (3 first level, 1 first and one second level, or 1 third level).

The spell may be used for memorisation, or may be used to hold onto the memory of a spell just cast.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: an aura has been added, so as to be visible and persistant while a caster moves, to represent the ring effect with a default size of 10' radius.  After it is applied to a caster it can be changed on their details tab to any size up to the stated 10 ft + 3 ft radius/level.

A separate shape effect is given in 20 ft blocks for a caster to detail on a map (in 20 ft chunks) the size of the spell if casting it as a wall. - Ed.]

 

General

A magic user's Wall of Fire does base damage of [[/roll 2d6]] hit points plus 1 hp/level. If the wall is configured as a ring its radius will be 10 ft + 3 ft/level. In all other respects, the spell resembles the druidic spell Wall of Fire.

 

REFERENCED TEXT:

...a blazing inferno of flame in the shape of a wall. One side of the conflagration emits the searing heat one would expect, but the other side emits merely a gentle warmth.

The wall persists for as long as the magic user concentrates upon it.  [Foundry Note: - concentration precludes movement or any other action.  If the druid desires to move they must stop concentrating to do so. - Ed.]

If the magic user does not choose to maintain concentration, it remains for 1 round/caster level. 

The druid may evoke a Wall of Fire in one of two shapes.

Straight wall:

  • up to one 20 ft square per caster level arranged as desired
  • a wall is stationary

Ring:

  • radius of up to 10 ft + 3 ft/level (caster in centre)
  • 20 ft high
  • A ring moves with the caster

 

Saves and Other Impediments

No saving throws are allowed to avoid or reduce taken from the wall.

 

Combat Effects

Passing through the flames inflicts [[/roll 2d6]] hit points plus 1 hp/level. Additionally:

  • Creatures as far as 10 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 2d4]] hit points of damage.
  • Creatures between 10 and 20 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 1d4]] points of damage.

Undead creatures suffer worse from the power of this...magic, taking twice the ordinary damage the wall would inflict.

actions.name: Wall of Fire
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) to visualize a ring casting, target the caster and click the  "Ring Aura - (C)" action, which has no mechanical function but provides a visual indication of the AOE which moves with the caster
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize a wall casting's area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
    • As the AOE can be shaped within reason to the caster's desire, the castshape provides individual 20x20 "blocks" of AOE which may be built into a specific final AOE by re-clicking the action and placing more blocks
  • If the caster stops concentrating (to move or attack, for example) target the caster and click the  "WOF Post-Concentration - Duration (C)" action to start the finite duration
  • If an undead actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the undead actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • if the undead actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 4d4 Fire)" action
    • If the undead actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Undead Wall Touch" action
  • If any other actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 1d4 Fire)" action
    • if the actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • If the actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Wall Touch" action

biography.value:
Background Noble: The second daughter of Queen Yolande, Princess Valerys Aravae Loravalur Mystralath grew up an impetuous child, full of mischievous and playful desires. Her Mother, the Queen, never had time for her, and she was raised by a nurse and courtiers at teh High Court of Celene. She learned all the Etiquette required of a young noble elf girl.She was bright and had exceptional coordination, agility, reflexes, precision and balance. At a young age, all she wanted to do was learn how to dance. Later in life, she strove to use her incredible intelligence to master the Art of Magic. 

At the age of one hundred and one with her prospects dimmed and little chance of ever serving in a High Court, Valerys struck out to become an adventurer. She left the Capitol city of Enstad of the Elven Kingdom of Celene in search of excitement. Always dreaming of Magic, she embarked to become a Magic-User, and after twelve years of study, she became one and continued to study her craft for decades.


The studious life of a Tower Mage was uneventful and rather dull, so Val once again set her sight on the distant horizon and set off for more adventure. She soon found herself in the company of thieves, and became one of them. She learned all of the thieving arts and did quite well. Yet after seventeen years, she grew bored with Thieves Guild activity and struck out on her own once again. Finally leaving The Kingdom at the still young age of 180, Valerys wandered the realms, looking for adventure. Valerys will never inherit anything of value back home in Celene. Valerys has not ventured back to the Kingdom of Celene since she left almost a year ago, but she still holds her signet ring in high regard and wears it proudly on her finger. As the daughter of a Noble House of the Faerie Kingdom of Celene, Valerys Mystralath is expected to return from time to time to fulfill her duties. As an adventurer she goes by the name of 'Val' and does not let on that she is of noble birth and in line to succeed to the throne of the Faerie Kingdom of Celene.

system.description:
General

Elves are thinner and generally smaller in stature than humans. The elves have a powerful bond with nature and do not have souls; their thinking and motives are quite alien to those of humankind, and in any dealings with elves, it is perilous to forget this.

Some elven clans have built elaborate civilisations, remote and beautiful places of profound learning, master craftsmanship, and long history. Such elves tend to be chaotic good in alignment and friendly, if aloof, from humans. More numerous are the wilder elves, predominantly chaotic neutral in alignment and often not friendly to other races, inclining even toward hostility.

Intruding into the territory of such elves is inadvisable, for their sense of humour with regard to humans is, at best, arbitrary and, at worst, cruel. Different as they are, these varied elven cultures all share the same racial abilities, unless the GM chooses otherwise. Elves can live to an age of 1,000 years or more.

 

Summary of Elven Racial Abilities

  • +1 dexterity, -1 constitution
  • 90% resistance to sleep and charm spells

 

Any pulled bow: +1 to hit

 

Longsword and short sword: +1 to hit

 

Languages:

  • common
  • elven
  • gnoll
  • gnomish
  • goblin
  • halfling
  • hobgoblin
  • orcish 

Languages in addition to these are only possible if the character has an intelligence of 16+, with one additional language possible for each point of intelligence over 15.

 

Infravision: 60 ft

 

Detect secret doors:

  • 1 in 6 chance to notice secret doors if passing within 10 ft
  • 2 in 6 chance to discover secret doors when searching 
  • 3 in 6 chance to discover concealed doors when searching

 

Surprise: 4 in 6 chance to surprise when travelling in nonmetal armour and alone, or more than 90 ft in advance of others, or with a party entirely consisting of elves and/or halflings.

If a door must be opened (or some similar task), the chance of surprise drops to 2 in 6.

 

Multi-class restrictions: The less restrictive of any two class requirements apply to multi-classed elven characters, except that thieving abilities can only be used while wearing armour permitted to thieves

 

Permitted Class Options:

  • Assassin
  • Cleric
  • Fighter
  • Magic user
  • Thief
  • Fighter/Magic user
  • Fighter/Thief
  • Magic user/Thief
  • Fighter/ Magic user/Thief

 

Movement Rate: 120 ft

 

Starting Age:

Cleric [[/roll 500+10d10]]
Fighter [[/roll 130+5d6]]
Magic User [[/roll 150+5d6]]
Thief [[/roll 100+5d6]]

[Foundry Note: sub-classes are as main class. if multi-classed, roll whichever of the classes included could produce the highest starting age. - Ed.]

 

Racial Limitations:

Minimum/Maximum ability scores (after adjustment for race); if the ability scores rolled do not fall within these limits, then the race of Elf is not a valid choice for the character:

Attribute Min Max
Strength 3 18
Dexterity 7 19
Constitution 8 17
Intelligence 8 18
Wisdom 3 18
Charisma 8 18

 

Level Limitations:

Assassin 10
Cleric 7
Druid N/A
Fighter 7 (Str 18), 6 (Str 17), 5 (Str 16 and below)
Illusionist N/A
Magic User 11 (Int 18+), 10 (Int 17), 9 (Int 16 and below)
Paladin N/A
Ranger N/A
Thief Unlimited

[Foundry Note:  This "weapon" is included in the non-lethal skill bundle and doesn't require a separate drop on an actor sheet. 

All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat: Brawling attacks, such as those conducted with fist, foot, or dagger pommel, will normally inflict [[/roll 1d2]] points of damage.

[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - grapple: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

Unarmed combat - overbearing: Overbearing attacks are Grappling attacks exercised at the end of a Charge (see "Charge" above). If successful, the opponent is prone rather than restrained. Otherwise the attack is treated as a grapple.

Referenced Text: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

Referenced Text: Charge: Charging into combat allows the attacker to move and then attack in the same round. A charge is made at twice the normal movement rate (and must terminate within the 10-ft melee range of the target). If the defender has a longer weapon than the attacker, the defender attacks first (unless the defender has already acted in this round). The attacker gains no dexterity bonus against such an attack (and characters with no dexterity bonus receive a +1 AC penalty). Additionally, if the defender has a weapon set against the charge (see below), he or she will inflict additional damage with a successful hit against the charging attacker.

Assuming that the charging character survives, he or she gains +2 "to hit" on his or her attack. Characters may only perform a charge once every 10 rounds (i.e. once per turn). Characters who are at the maximum encumbrance category may not charge unless they are mounted and the mount is below the maximum encumbrance category.

[Foundry Note: if an elf character doesn't choose a class able to use this weapon, or doesn't take a weapon proficiency in the weapon, this ability does not in itself grant weapon proficiency or allow a class to use a weapon it can't otherwise use. It is only intended to give an additional +1 above and beyond what a non-elf would gain with the same weapon in their hands.

If a character is built in such a way the skill has no purpose, it may be deleted off that character's sheet to avoid clutter. - Ed.]

When employing a bow of any sort other than a crossbow or when using a short or long sword, elves gain a bonus of +1 to their attack rolls.

Thieves and assassins have an enhanced chance to hear noise as they gain levels (see “thief skills” in Chapter I). Characters of all other classes have a base 10% chance. This should be modified by race; elves, gnomes, halflings, and half-orcs have a base 15% chance.  (In Foundry, these races have a 5% bonus added to their skill check target number automatically when the skill is used- Ed.)

 

Hear - Base Chance/Target Formula

Assassin Thief
Level  Target Range Level Target Range
1 10% 1 10%
2 10% 2 13%
3 10% 3 16%
4 13% 4 19%
5 16% 5 22%
6 19% 6 25%
7 22% 7 28%
8 25% 8 31%
9 28% 9 34%
10 31% 10 37%
11 34% 11 40%
12 37% 12 43%
13 40% 13 46%
14 43% 14 49%
15 46% 15 52%
    16 55%
    17 58%
    18 61%
    19 64%
    20 67%
    21 70%
    22 73%
    23 76%
    24 79%

 

Normally the GM rolls this die in secret, because the player has no way of knowing whether no noise was heard because of the roll or because there was no noise to hear. A character who fails (or thinks he or she has failed) to hear noise may try again, each attempt taking one round. However, no more than three attempts may be made the same character before the strain becomes too great and no further listening attempts will succeed until the character has rested for at least one turn.

If the check is successful, the GM should decide whether there is in fact any noise to be heard. Some monsters, such as bugbears, are stealthy and cannot be detected by listening. However, generally if there is some monster in the area and a “hear noise” check is passed, the party should gain some clue about what it is. Clever players whose characters speak various monster languages may gain valuable information from overhearing snatches of conversation—but the GM should be careful only to describe what characters can actually hear. So the GM would not normally say “you hear a giant spider,” but rather “you hear a scuttling, rattling sound” as the creature climbs to a suitable spot from which to ambush the party.

Don’t forget, monsters can hear the party in the same way as the party can hear them!
system.dmonlytext:
Listening for noise as often as possible, at every door and intersection, is an understandably common tactic, because it’s one of the easiest ways for players to improve the odds in their favour — so as to be able to make better-informed decisions about their actions. This is fine in moderation. However, if the pace of play slows considerably, diminishing the excitement and reducing the adventure to dice-rolling, the GM should discourage the players from endless listening attempts. Emphasise the inconvenience of donning and doffing helmets and headgear while the rest of the party stands around doing nothing; and if play is still slow, employ tricks that circumvent listening, e.g. silent monsters or phantom noises (perhaps due to strange acoustics in the dungeon or magic). In extreme cases the GM can place traps and monsters that specifically target listening characters, but before it gets to that, the GM should speak frankly to the players and explain that while some degree of caution is good play, carrying things to extremes only makes the game less fun.

Balance this against the lethality of the dungeon. In extremely dangerous areas, the players should not be punished for taking due care.

  • 2 in 6 chance to discover secret doors when searching,
  • 3 in 6 chance to discover concealed doors when searching.

4 in 6 chance to surprise when travelling in nonmetal armour and alone, or more than 90 ft in advance of others, or with a party entirely consisting of elves and/or halflings. If a door must be opened (or some similar task), the chance of surprise drops to 2 in 6.

It is only intended to give an additional +1 above and beyond what a non-elf would gain with the same weapon in their hands.

If a character is built in such a way the skill has no purpose, it may be deleted off that character's sheet to avoid clutter. - Ed.]

 

When employing a bow of any sort other than a crossbow or when using a short or long sword, elves gain a bonus of +1 to their attack rolls.
This is used to determine success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door that doesn't open easily (this is the average dungeon door).
This is used to attempt an extraordinary success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door enspelled by minor magics such as Hold Portal or Wizard Lock.

General

Magic users are a rare breed - practitioners of the mysterious art of arcane spell casting. A lengthy apprenticeship of study and practice allows these somewhat eerie individuals to store arcane energy within their minds and to release it in the form of spells.

Magic users cast spells by speaking a few magic words, weaving complex gestures in the air, and employing rare and magical materials. While magic users (with illusionists) are the weakest character class in combat, this weakness is balanced by possessing the most powerful and versatile spells in the game.

The full underlying principles of magic are beyond mortal comprehension; even wizards of the profoundest intellect struggle from momentary inklings to understand its more complex patterns. Nevertheless, those character who possess formidable intelligence and a certain intuitive gift, who are willing to devote themselves to a lifetime of study, may in time sufficiently master the art to be capable of shifting mountains and shattering entire armies. High-level magic users are the most feared and dangerous characters in the game.

Magic users do not gain bonus spells for high intelligence scores; intelligence does determine which spells they can understand and how many spells they may learn for each spell level.

Magic users are dependent upon their spell books, and normally may only cast spell they have learned from these books (exception: magic users may cast spells from arcane magical scrolls). Mages may not cast spells from divine, druidic or phantasmal magic scrolls.

The acquisition of a new spell is difficult and demanding and must normally be accomplished through adventuring, although the mage will automatically receive one new spell of the highest spell level that he or she may cast upon acquiring a new level of experience.

OSRIC magic users are superficially similar to the wizards of fantasy literature such as Gandalf and Merlin, but they are more closely similar to mages described in the works of Jack Vance. His "Dying Earth" cycle, and particularly "Rhialto the Marvellous", are highly recommended.

Magic users are the only class capable of fabricating magic items that they cannot themselves employ. Clerics, druids and illusionists can fabricate magic items, but only those they themselves can use; items such as magical swords, that no primary spell casting class may use, are in their creation the sole province of magic users.

At 11th level, a magic user may establish a stronghold (usually a tower or small keep) in the same manner as a fighter.

 

Minimum Scores: Str 3, Dex 6, Int 9, Wis 6,Con 6, Cha 6

 

Hit Die Type: d4 (max 11)

 

Alignment: Any

 

Experience bonus: Int 16+

 

Armour/Shield Permitted: None

 

Weapons Permitted: Dagger, dart, oil, staff

 

Weapon Proficiencies: 1, +1 per 5 levels

 

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -5

 

Weapon Specialisation: N/A

 

Magic User Class Abilities

Spellcasting: Magic users may memorise and cast arcane spells in accordance with the tables provided below.

A beginning magic user character will know four spells. One of these will automatically be Read Magic. The second spell should be chosen by the player from the list of first level spells, and the last two should be determined randomly from the list of first level spells.

 

Intelligence Score Chance to Understand Spells (d%) Minimum/Maximum Spells Understood Per Level
9 35 4/6
10-12 45 5/7
13-14 55 6/9
15-16 65 7/11
17 75 8/14
18 85 9/18
19 90 10/22

 

Eldritch Craft (7th): Mages of 7th or higher level may create magical potions, scribe arcane scrolls (of spells that he or she already knows) and recharge magical rods, staves and wands. This process should be overseen by the GM, who must take care to ensure that it is not too easy! A long list of ingredients will always be required, some of which should be expensive, and others of which should be a challenge to acquire.

 

Perceive Magical Surveillance (7th): [Foundry Note: the inclusion of this skill is a Foundry-specific addition.  Also please note that the specific target number for this skill is determined both by level and INT score, so 7th is simply the earliest level a magic user could possibly emply it.  See the skill description to determine the specific target number for any actor. If current level/INT doesn't qualify an actor to use the skill, set the target number to "0" until the actor does qualify. The target number likely requires adjustment in any case as levels are gained. - Ed.]

 

Eldritch Power (12th): Magic users of 12th level or higher may attempt to create other magical items by means of the enchant an item spell. However, this is even more difficult than creating a potion or scroll, and the various components required should be of a rarity and value appropriate to the magic item under consideration. Even then, success will not be guaranteed.

General

Thieves sneak furtively in the shadowed alleyways of cities, living by their wits. They are often members of the criminal underclass, usually trained by a thieves' guild in the arts of burglary and stealth. It is not uncommon for a thief to seek out the great rewards that can be gained from the adventuring life, especially when circumstances require lying low for a while.

Most thieves come from the teeming masses of a large city, wherein a thieves' guild is often the only source of justice and exercises as much power as the city's legitimate government. Of course, not all thieves are members of a guild. Some are freelancers, evading both the authorities and the guild, living on the edge of the knife. Some are even found working on the side of the law; agents or spies who use their skills in more accepted (though equally shadowy) pursuits.

A thief character must be of any neutral or evil alignment. Neutral good thieves are permitted because of the neutral component of their alignment.

Sensible adventuring parties will almost always include a thief, for the skills of such a character are invaluable in reaching inaccessible places via climb walls, pick locks, and so on. In addition, dungeons frequently contain traps which must be located and disarmed, and the thief's cunning and stealth conspire to make him or her very useful in a scouting role.

Thieves in OSRIC are modelled on characters of fiction and legend, particularly characters from the works of Fritz Leiber and Jack Vance. Leiber's "Lankhmar" series is highly recommended, particularly for its description of the operation of a typical thieves' guild; but the high-level thief's ability to read (or misread) magic scrolls is a nod to Vance's Cugel.

 

Minimum Scores: Str 6, Dex 9, Con 6, Int 6,Cha 6

 

Hit Die Type: d6

 

Initial Hit Die: 1

 

Alignment: Any neutral or any evil

 

Experience bonus: Dex 16+

 

Armour/Shield Permitted: Leather or studded leather only, no shields

 

Weapons Permitted: Club, dagger, dart, oil, sling, single-handed swords (except bastard swords)

 

Weapon Proficiencies: 2, +1 every 4 levels

 

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -3

 

Weapon Specialisation: N/A

 

Thief Class Abilities

Backstab: If the thief can approach his or her target unobserved and strike with a melee weapon, the attack is made at +4 to hit. Damage from a backstab is doubled - or trebled if the thief is of 5th level or higher. Thieves of 9th level or higher do quadruple damage, while those of 13th or greater level quintuple the number shown on the die. Damage modifiers (such as those pertaining to strength or magic) are not multiplied from a backstab.

Climb: Climbing represents a thief's ability to scale sheer walls and surfaces, cling to ceilings, and perform other feats of climbing that would normally be impossible. Climbing checks must ordinarily be repeated for every ten ft of climbing. Non-thieves cannot climb walls, cliffs, or any vertical surface without the use of a rope or magic, making the presence of a thief vital to many adventuring parties.

 

Find Traps: This ability represents the thief's minute visual inspection of a new area for tiny telltale signs that something of interest or danger may be concealed nearby. It requires a full turn (10 minutes) to accomplish.

 

Hide in Shadows: Some shadow must be present for this ability to be used, but if the check is successful the thief is effectively invisible until he makes an attack or moves from the shadows. The ability can also be used to blend in with a crowd of people rather than disappear into shadows.

 

Move Quietly: Use of this skill allows the thief to move with preternatural silence even over surfaces such as squeaky floors.

 

Open Locks/ Disarm Traps: Opening locks and disarming traps (without springing them) is a skill unique to thieves, which cannot be successfully attempted by members of other classes. A thief can also set traps (with the same chance as to disarm).

 

Pick Pockets: If the thief's pick pockets check fails by 20% or more, then his or her attempt has been discovered and the intended victim will almost always take hostile action.

 

Read Languages: The thief may attempt to read languages and ciphers of a non-magical nature only.

 

Thieves' Cant: Thieves have their own language.

 

Advanced Abilities

Read Scrolls (10th): When a thief reaches 10th level, he or she has become well-versed enough in training to cast spells from an arcane or phantasmal scroll (magic user or illusionist). However, this casting is not always successful. The thief should roll against his or her intelligence as a magic user or illusionist does, and if the score shown on the die is insufficient for the thief to cast the spell, then the casting will fail, possibly (at the GM's option) having some entirely unexpected effect.

Note: Subject to the GM's discretion, no combination of adjustments can reduce a thief's chance of success in a thieving skill below 1% or increase it above 99%. In other words, there is always a small chance of success or risk of failure unless the GM decides the circumstances are exceptional.

Magic users of 7th or higher level may create magical potions, scribe arcane scrolls (of spells that he or she already knows) and recharge magical rods, staves and wands.  Magic users are the only class capable of fabricating magic items that they cannot themselves employ.

Clerics, druids, and illusionists of 7th or higher level also have this ability, limited to items they can use (although other classes may use this item also).  An illusionist, for example, could create a potion of healing but not a potion of heroism.

This is a passive chance for some actors or monsters that use spells or spell-like actions, and which also are some combination of powerful and intelligent to notice when someone attempts to surveill them magically by spell (Clairvoyance, Clairaudience, ESP, etc.) or magic items (Crystal Ball, etc.).

Daoud's Wondrous Lanthorn: This artifact is wrought from the
finest yellow gold. Its beautifully crafted framework is set with
huge jewels and crystal lenses. An unwavering pure flame
burns within. The faces are normally fitted with the crystal
lenses, but the jewels are actually additional lenses, fashioned
to fit the four faces of the lanthorn. The lanthorn's magical
powers change, depending upon which of the gem lenses are
fitted to it, as well as upon the continued burning of the lan-
thorn's magical flame.
system.dmonlytext:
The flame of Daoud's Lanthorn cannot be extinguished by any
known means, other than by exhausting its supply of fuel. The
lamp is fueled by crushed transparent gems, contained in a
small compartment at the base of the lanthorn. The lanthorn
can be refuelled with the following amounts of gems:
1. Crushed diamonds, total worth 10,000 gp.
2. Crushed oriental topazes, rubies, sapphires, total worth
4,000 gp for each gem type.
3. Miscellaneous crushed transparent gems of seven differ-
ent colors, total worth 15,000 gp. Each gem must be worth
500 gp or more.
The lanthorn will always be burning when found, and will
always be fully fueled. If fuel is placed in the extinguished
lanthorn, it will magically light itself. If used as a normal lan-
thorn, it will burn for 100 years. The use of its magical powers
burns fuel at a faster rate. If the flame of the lanthorn goes out
for any reason, the possessor of the lanthorn will instantly die!
The four faces of the lanthorn can be shuttered so that no light
shines through, but infravision or ultravision will see it as a
glowing object. If all four openings of the lanthorn are fitted
with the crystal lenses, anyone exposed to the lanthorn's glow
for four consecutive hours will not need food, drink, or sleep
for a further twelve hours. Twenty-four consecutive hours of
exposure to the light will cure 1d4+4 points of damage and
temporarily halt the effects of disease or poison. Seven con-
tinuous days of exposure will destroy all disease or poison in
the person basking in the light.
(Dungeon Master's Note: Seven gem prisms were made for the
lanthorn, as listed below. When the lanthorn is found, it will
have the following prisms with it: ruby, topaz, emerald, dia-
mond, and the four crystal lenses. The three remaining gem
prisms are elsewhere—possibly the object of a quest by player
characters.
Should any of the gem prisms be broken in use, replacement
lenses can be made. This will require a single huge gemstone
worth at least 10,000 gp, of the same type as the one that was
broken. The new lens must be prepared by a gemcutter of
superb skill (DMG, pg. 30), and the gemcutter must be given
one of the other lenses to use as a guide. A magic-user must
then cast enchant an item on the lens, followed by the spell that
matches the original len's power. A permanency spell must
then be cast on the lens. Due to the nature of the lanthorn's
magical flame, only lenses that duplicate the listed ones will
function—no original lenses can be made. The possibility of
making new lenses for the lanthorn should be a secret that
player characters will discover only after time-consuming and
expensive research).
The magical effects of the lanthorn have a range of 30.' The
power of the artifact is such that, at ranges of 10' or less,
there is no saving throw against the lanthorn's magic,
nor will magic resistance protect against it.

When three openings of the lanthorn are shuttered, and a gem
prism inserted in the remaining opening, a beam of colored
light shines forth 30'. However, the magical power of the lens
does not take effect until the possessor of the lanthorn com-
mands it. The magical power of a single prism affects only
single target. Gem prisms can also be combined to produce
different effects. The gem prisms, their effects, and their fuel
costs, are:

 Type of Prism  Lanthorn Effect  Fuel Cost
 Ruby  Hold Person/Monster  5
 Emerald  Haste  5
 Diamond  Color Spray  5
 Sapphire  Fear  5
 Amethyst  Emotion (rage)  5
 Jacinth  Flame Strike  5
 Special  Confusion  10
 Special  Prismatic Spray  50
 Special  Prismatic Sphere  50

The effect of each single prism is as the appropriate spell. The
magical power of a single prism affects only one victim per use.
The listed fuel is burned each time the given spell effect is
used. An effect cannot be used if there is not enough fuel left in
the lanthorn to "pay" for it. The confusion, prismatic spray, and
prismatic sphere effects require combinations of seven
prisms.
All spell effects are equal to 19th level spell use, except that the
prismatic sphere and prismatic spray effects have a duration of
one turn per use.
If a gem prism is placed in each opening of the lanthorn, and the
lanthorn is then spun, all within 30' of the lanthorn, except the
possessor, will be confused, as the spell. Victims within 10' of
the lanthorn receive no saving throw. This effect operates in
the command of the lanthorn's possessor, as do all other 
effects. Any combination of four gem lenses will produce this
effect.
If all seven prisms are possessed, and the owner of the lan-
thorn mounts all seven, one behind another, to an unshuttered
opening, a prismatic spray is produced. Each use of the pris-
matic spray has a 10% chance of shattering 1-4 prisms. The
seven lens can be arranged in any order.
If the seven prisms are arranged so as to have two lenses in
three of the openings and the diamond lens in the fourth,
prismatic sphere is created. The proper sequence is: ruby and
jacinth; topaz and emerald; sapphire and amethyst; diamond.

A full round is needed to open or close all the shutters of the
lanthorn. Placing or removing a lens from one of the openings
requires one round. Thus, two rounds are needed to exchange
one gem lens for a different one. In a melee or other confused
situation where the lanthorn's owner is in danger, there is a
10% chance (rolled secretly by the DM) that the wrong prism
has accidentally been inserted. However, since the magical
effects operate on command, the owner can avoid unwanted
results by examining the lanthorn before its powers are used.
Legend states that the wrong combinations of gem fuel will
cause the lanthorn'to malfunction. Possible mishaps include:
totally different magical powers; powers that affect the lan-
thorn's owner as well as the intended target; deluding the
owner as to the actual powers of the lanthorn; becoming a
non-magical lanthorn.
Anyone who owns Daoud's Wondrous Lanthorn will become
increasingly possessive of it, suspicious of those who look at
the lanthorn, and increasingly secretive about it.
This obsession with the lanthorn will become a form of para-
noia (DMG, pg. 84) and the owner will become convinced that
"they" want to kill him or her and steal the lanthorn.
Daoud's Lanthorn is an artifact of g reat power and worth a vast
sum if sold. It is known that an offer of 160,000 gp was made for
the device, with but four of the seven prisms available. One can
only speculate what the price would be if all seven gem lenses
were included.

actionGroups.name: Hold Monster: Hold Monster (One Target)
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: For actors able to partially negate their paralysis by some means, and thus under the effects of a Slow spell, the GM will need to track halved number of attacks for slowed creatures manually. 

As monsters often move at greater speeds, six movement rate effects are provided which halve the common base move rates of 180, 150, 120, 90, 60, and 30, for the GM to selectively apply if applicable. - Ed.]

 

General

A hold monster spell completely immobilises up to four creatures of any kind for the spell's duration.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The magic user decides how many of his or her foes he or she will target with the spell:

  • if there is only one target, the saving throw is made at -3,
  • if two targets, each makes the saving throw at -1, and
  • if three or four targets, each makes the saving throw with no penalty.

If a magic item or spell operates to partially negate the effects of paralysis, failure on the saving throw will have the effect of a Slow spell rather than completely immobilising the target.

 

Combat Effects

[Another common houserule is that creatures may only be attacked at 2x rate, but not slain, if a battle is ongoing and the incapacitated person isn't otherwise isolated from allies. - Ed.]

Creatures held by this spell may be killed or bound at a rate of one per round, or, if the attacker chooses, may be attacked at twice the normal rate with an automatic hit, for maximum damage.

actions.name: Hold Monster (One Target)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the enemy actor(s)
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done)
  • if the saving throw fails click the  "Held - Duration (T)" action
  • If the saving throw is made, click whichever movement action results in a 50% reduction of the target's movement rate.

actionGroups.name: Hold Monster: Hold Monster (Two Targets)
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: For actors able to partially negate their paralysis by some means, and thus under the effects of a Slow spell, the GM will need to track halved number of attacks for slowed creatures manually. 

As monsters often move at greater speeds, six movement rate effects are provided which halve the common base move rates of 180, 150, 120, 90, 60, and 30, for the GM to selectively apply if applicable. - Ed.]

 

General

A hold monster spell completely immobilises up to four creatures of any kind for the spell's duration.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The magic user decides how many of his or her foes he or she will target with the spell:

  • if there is only one target, the saving throw is made at -3,
  • if two targets, each makes the saving throw at -1, and
  • if three or four targets, each makes the saving throw with no penalty.

If a magic item or spell operates to partially negate the effects of paralysis, failure on the saving throw will have the effect of a Slow spell rather than completely immobilising the target.

 

Combat Effects

[Another common houserule is that creatures may only be attacked at 2x rate, but not slain, if a battle is ongoing and the incapacitated person isn't otherwise isolated from allies. - Ed.]

Creatures held by this spell may be killed or bound at a rate of one per round, or, if the attacker chooses, may be attacked at twice the normal rate with an automatic hit, for maximum damage.

actions.name: Hold Monster (Two Targets)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the enemy actor(s)
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done)
  • if the saving throw fails click the  "Held - Duration (T)" action
  • If the saving throw is made, click whichever movement action results in a 50% reduction of the target's movement rate.

actionGroups.name: Haste
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: the GM will need to track doubled number of attacks for hasted creatures manually, but four movement rate effects are provided which double the common effective move rates of 120, 90, 60, and 30, for the GM to selectively apply if desired.

Also, be aware a common house rule is that Haste, and similar magic such as potions of speed, cause a system shock which must be rolled at risk of death if failed. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell imbues creatures in the targeted area with preternatural speed.

The spell ages the creatures upon which it is cast by 2 years.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Within the area of effect, if the caster's level is not sufficient to affect all of the creatures in the area, creatures closest to the caster will be affected first by the spell. 

Haste and Slow automatically cancel each other without any shocks to the systems of those affected.

 

Combat Effects

Affected creatures move and attack at twice the normal rate.

The rate of spell casting cannot be increased.

actions.name: Haste
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target chosen actors in the AOE and click the movement action corresponding to the actor's current movement rate

actionGroups.name: Colour Spray
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: as the affected creatures within the AOE (including allies!) is random, the primary casting has no "save"; The save in the 2nd cast can be used surgically; apply the save to the randomly determined subset within the AOE (including allies!) - Ed.]

 

General

The caster fans out his or her fingers, and a sheet of unearthly-coloured light springs forth. [[/roll 1d6]] creatures caught within the light may be affected, and the spell can only affect 1 hit die of creatures per caster level.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Any creature with hit dice exceeding the caster's (and creatures or 6+ HD regardless of the caster's level) are entitled to a saving throw.

 

Combat Effects

Creatures with HD equal to or less than the caster's are rendered unconscious by the burst of colours for [[/roll 2d4]] rounds.

If the creature's hit dice exceed the caster's by 1 or 2, the creature is blinded for [[/roll 1d4]] rounds.

[Foundry Note: as with the Light spell, two implementations of blindness are provided.  "STATUS blind" doesn't allow targeting to work if making penalized attacks, and so all subsequent attacks must be handled entirely manually.  Use the version you prefer. - Ed.]

If the creature has 3+ hit dice in excess of the caster's, it is merely stunned for [[/roll 2d4]] segments.

[Foundry Note: This stun effect is <1 absolute round, but may carry over into the next round, and other allied attacks might come during the duration; apply and manually delete the effect when the 2d4 segments have passed. - Ed.]

actions.name: Colour Spray
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Determine the number of actors ( [[/roll 1d6]] ) which will be targeted, and then randomly determine which actors within the AOE are those targets
  • Target all of the indicated actors and click "Save vrs Spells" 
  • Target actors with hit dice =< the caster that fail saves and click the  "Unconscious - Duration (T)" action
  • Target actors with 1 or 2 hit dice > the caster that fail saves and click whichever  blinded action the GM prefers used in their campaign
  • Target actors with 3+ hit dice > the caster that fail saves and click the  "Stunned (T)" action
    • These actors are only stunned for [[/roll 2d4]] segments, which may be less than a round or possibly stretch across parts of two rounds - remove the effect after the determined number of segments elapses

actionGroups.name: Flame Strike
actionGroups.description:
General

Upon the casting of this spell, a blazing column of fire descends from the air. Its searing flames engulf an area 10 ft in diameter, as set by the caster.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Base damage is halved if the creature makes a successful saving throw.

 

Combat Effects

Each creature caught within the flames will suffer [[/roll 6d8]] points of damage.

actions.name: Flame Strike
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors (ally or enemy) in the AOE
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and force saving throws
  • Click the  "Damage - (6d8 Fire)" action

system.description:
@UUID[RollTable.4bEHV1JR3K4cMXMl]{Rings - Chance of Failure (Dwarf, Gnome, Halfling)}

[Foundry Note: as with scrolls, some spells have more than one form which are exclusive - if you cast one form the other(s) don't remain to be cast later.  If any such spells are in the ring, the player and GM will need to work together fairly to remove charges from uncast parallel forms of a used spell. - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

A ring that can magically store 2-5 spells (which can't be changed after item creation) and grants the wearer the ability to cast them as if he or she were a 12th level spell caster of the required type.

Casting a spell from the ring requires 5 segments.

Charging the ring requires a spell caster to cast the specific spell to be stored with the ring as the target of the spell.
system.dmonlytext:
XP/GP Value

@UUID[RollTable.bhTLYvZJqwDj6qZA]{Magic Ring-as-Jewellery Value}

 

Apparent (Jewellery) Value: ?

(True) GPV: 25,000 gp

 

General (Ring)

Magic rings appear indistinguishable from ordinary finger jewellery of varying types, though a Detect Magic spell cast upon them will cause them to radiate a magic aura. With the exception of a wish spell, the only way to determine the function of a magic ring is to put it on.

A maximum of two rings can be worn by any PC or NPC at a time; only one ring may be worn per hand. Attempting to wear additional magic rings will render all worn magical rings useless. Magic rings worn on toes or as earrings will not function.

Unless noted otherwise, the abilities a ring grants function as if cast by a 12th level spell caster, or the minimum level required to cast the spell if greater than 12th.

Because of the innate magical resistance of dwarfs, gnomes, and halflings; magic rings have a 20% chance per use of not working at all and, if cursed, the curse will fail. In such a case the wearer recognises the cursed properties of the ring and can easily remove it from his or her finger.

 

Ring of Spell Storing - GM Information

[Foundry Note: if randomly generating the ring with the provided table, when dragging the spells into the ring's Actions tab be sure to set the initiative delay to "5" for all spells and update all level-variable aspects of the spell to that of a 12th level caster.]

 

@Compendium[world.osric-gm-table.WcFTwbg57S2uTOfn]{Table: 06.344 Rings - Ring of Spell Storing Random Generation}

 

Roll d%, a roll of 01-70 means the ring stores magic user spells and 71-00 indicates clerical spells. 10% of magic user rings of spell storing will contain illusionist spells instead, and 25% of clerical rings of spell storing will contain druid spells instead.

Roll [[/roll 2d4]] to determine number of spells the ring can contain. To randomly determine the spell levels of each spell, roll [[/roll 1d6]] (on a result of 6 re-roll for level with [[/roll 1d4]]) for cleric, druid or illusionist spells, and [[/roll 1d8]] (on a result of 8 re-roll for level with [[/roll 1d6]]) for magic user spells.

Once type, number, and level of spells is determined, the GM must decide which spells the ring contains. The spells can either be hand-picked or the GM may use the OSRIC magic tables and dice for spells randomly.

Once the class of spells, their number and level, and the exact spells to be stored are determined, that capability can never be changed.

 

Example of Ring of Spell Storing Creation:

Jerry the GM decides to place a ring of spell storing in a red dragon's treasure hoard. He rolls a 57 on d%, indicating the ring contains magic user spells. A second d% roll yields a 05 and this means the ring really contains spells of the illusionist class.

Jerry now rolls [[/roll 2d4]] and gets 1 on both dice, meaning the ring will contain 2 spells total. Jerry now rolls [[/roll 1d6]] twice, one for each spell to determine the level of that spell. The first result is a 2, the second is a 6. The 6 needs to be re-rolled on a [[/roll 1d4]] and rolling that die generates a result of 4.

So, the GM now knows the ring will hold 2 illusionist spells, one of level 2 and one of level 4. Jerry decides to let fate take a hand in the selection of the exact spells the ring stores and takes a look at the illusionist spell tables (see Chapter 2).

There are twelve level 2 illusionist spells, and eight level 4 spells, so Jerry grabs a [[/roll 1d12]] and a [[/roll 1d8]] and rolls them both. The [[/roll 1d12]] rolls a 4 so Jerry notes the result of detect magic . The [[/roll 1d8]] rolls an 8 and Jerry notes the result of shadow monsters .

Now that the exact properties of the ring of spell storing have been determined, they can never be changed; the ring will ever after only hold the two illusionist spells noted. If the finder of the ring uses it to cast a detect magic spell, then an illusionist must cast a detect magic upon the ring to recharge that spell slot.

actions.name: Friends
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Enchantment/Charm

Sphere: MU

Level: 1

Cast Time: 1

Range: Caster

Duration: 1 round/level

Save: See below

AOE: 10 ft radius + 10 ft/level

Components: VSM

General

This spell increases the magic user's charisma in the eyes of all creatures within the area of effect that fail saving throws vs spells.

For creatures failing their saving throw, the magic user's charisma will effectively be increased by [[/roll 2d4]] (one roll for all).

For those who succeed in making the saving throw, the caster's charisma will effectively be lowered by [[/roll 1d4]].

Unless the exact numbers are required for some purpose, the normal result of the spell will be that those who failed the saving throw will be well-disposed and friendly toward the caster, and those that succeeded in making the save will find him or her distasteful and somewhat suspect.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors in the AOE and cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge, which will also trigger saving throws (this may already have been done)
  • For those that fail their save, click on the "Friends Save Failed - Duration (C)"
  • For those that make their save, click on the "Friends Save Made - Duration (C)"

actions.name: Jump
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: MU

Level: 1

Cast Time: 1

Range: Touch

Duration: See below

Save: None

AOE: One creature

Components: VSM

[Foundry Note: When this spell is cast, the GM could drag the spell on to the actor's Combat sheet as if creating a spell like power.  Give the "action" a casting time of 0, the type set to "Charged", and as many charges as the caster's level allows jumps.  As the caster uses up his jumps, have him "cast" the action until all charges are gone (or the spell is dispelled, whichever comes first). - Ed.]

 

General

This spell allows the subject to make one or more prodigious leaps, one additional leap for each three caster levels above 1. Thus, at a caster level of 4, the spell permits a second leap, with additional leaps at level 7, 10, 13, etc.

 

Combat Effects

The recipient of the spell may bound forward 30 ft, or may leap backward or straight up for a distance of 10 ft.

The leap is almost perfectly straight, with no arc.

actions.name: Shatter
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Transmutation/Alteration

Sphere: MU

Level: 2

Cast Time: 2

Range: 60 ft

Duration: Instantaneous

Save: Negates

AOE: One object

Components: VSM

General

This spell causes an item to shatter into pieces.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

It can affect objects of up to 10 lbs weight per caster level.

Only brittle materials are affected by the spell (glass, earthenware, etc.) excluding magical items of any kind.

The item is permitted an item saving throw against a crushing blow to avoid destruction.

 

Combat Effects

[Foundry Note: Some crystalline and other rare monsters may have vulnerabilties to this spell, and a personal (as opposed to item) saving throw casting is provided for these specific circumstances.]

actions.name: Invisibility
actions.description:
Type: Arcane

School: Illusion/Phantasm

Sphere: MU

Level: 2

Cast Time: 2

Range: Touch

Duration: See below

Save: None

AOE: One creature

Components: VSM

General

When the words of this spell are completed, the recipient and all he or she carries fade from sight, becoming invisible.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell remains in effect until the invisible creature attacks someone, the caster ends the spell, or the magic is dispelled. Note that the spell does not make the recipient any more quiet than normal, nor does it eliminate scents.

The invisible person can see him- or herself, but the caster (unless they are one and the same) cannot.

The spell cannot be cast upon an unwilling subject.

 

Combat Effects

Invisible opponent: An invisible opponent can only be attacked if the general location is known, and the attack is at –4 to hit.  

Even infravision cannot detect an invisible creature.

If an opponent is invisible to the attacker, he or she cannot be attacked from behind (or from the flank).

Note that more powerful monsters (those with sensitive smell or hearing, or more than six hit dice) will frequently be able to detect invisible opponents; the GM should determine the chance of this according to the creature concerned and the situation.

Powerful magical monsters, or those with more than 11 hit dice, will almost always be able to see invisible creatures normally.
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the ring wearer and click the "Invisible - Indefinite (T)" action
    • If the invisible actor makes an attack the invisibility is immediately deleted by the GM

system.description:
Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

Upon command, this cape will transform itself into a pair of wings, allowing the wearer to fly at 60 ft movement rate (aerial agility level IV - see Chapter 3).

When in cape form the wings of flying take on a variety of styles and appearances and the wings formed can be either feathered or bat-wing style.

Details

The ring also grants:

Apparent (Jewellery) Value: ?

(True) GPV: 5,000 gp

 

General (Ring)

Magic rings appear indistinguishable from ordinary finger jewellery of varying types, though a Detect Magic spell cast upon them will cause them to radiate a magic aura. With the exception of a wish spell, the only way to determine the function of a magic ring is to put it on.

A maximum of two rings can be worn by any PC or NPC at a time; only one ring may be worn per hand. Attempting to wear additional magic rings will render all worn magical rings useless. Magic rings worn on toes or as earrings will not function.

Unless noted otherwise, the abilities a ring grants function as if cast by a 12th level spell caster, or the minimum level required to cast the spell if greater than 12th.

Because of the innate magical resistance of dwarfs, gnomes, and halflings; magic rings have a 20% chance per use of not working at all and, if cursed, the curse will fail. In such a case the wearer recognises the cursed properties of the ring and can easily remove it from his or her finger.

General

This spell increases the magic user's charisma in the eyes of all creatures within the area of effect that fail saving throws vs spells.

For creatures failing their saving throw, the magic user's charisma will effectively be increased by [[/roll 2d4]] (one roll for all).

For those who succeed in making the saving throw, the caster's charisma will effectively be lowered by [[/roll 1d4]].

Unless the exact numbers are required for some purpose, the normal result of the spell will be that those who failed the saving throw will be well-disposed and friendly toward the caster, and those that succeeded in making the save will find him or her distasteful and somewhat suspect.

actions.name: Friends
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors in the AOE and cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge, which will also trigger saving throws (this may already have been done)
  • For those that fail their save, click on the "Friends Save Failed - Duration (C)"
  • For those that make their save, click on the "Friends Save Made - Duration (C)"

system.description:
General

Read Magic is normally the first spell in every magic user's spell book, and its mastery is the first task of every apprentice. The spell allows the caster to read magical writings (other than his or her own, of course, which are always intelligible to the original author).

Unless the writings are cursed, reading magical script does not normally activate the magic formulae described therein - reviewing a scroll prior to casting from it does not, for instance, actually cast whatever spell is written upon the scroll.

Once the magic user has read a particular set of magical inscriptions by use of this spell, the spell is no longer needed to re-read the writing at a later time.

The reverse of the spell is Indecipherable Magic.

actions.name: Read Magic
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Read Magic - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
General

While casting this spell, the magic user touches his or her thumbs together, and a sheet of flame explodes from his or her fingers

 

Saves and Other Impediments

No saving throw applies to physical damage taken by creatures.

Any combustible items caught in the sheet of flame must pass an item saving throw against normal fire or be destroyed.

 

Combat Effects

The flames burn opponents within the spell's short (3 ft) range, inflicting 1 hp of damage per caster level.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: it is a common house rule to only start the duration of the spell after the monsters appear. - Ed.]

 

General

By casting this spell, the magic user conjures up to [[/roll 2d4]] monsters to serve him or her as allies in combat or to perform other services. The monsters appear from thin air within [[/roll 1d4]] rounds of the spell's completed casting.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

For more complex tasks than simple combat, the magic user must somehow have the ability to communicate these more specific commands.

 

Combat Effects

If the caster is in combat, the monsters will fight on his or her behalf, attacking whatever foes he directs, or guarding him or her. 

The GM has the ultimate discretion as to what monsters will appear, but the general likelihood is described in the following table (Evil casters may get the monsters in parentheses, at the GM's option):

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.kvNMCUQTEb2UQ5M2]{Monster Summoning I}

 

d6 Monster Summoned
1 Rat, giant
2 Goblin (dwarf)
3 Hobgoblin (elf)
4 Kobold (halfling)
5 Orc (gnome)
6 Kullule (badger, giant)

actions.name: Monster Summoning I
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done) and click the @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.kvNMCUQTEb2UQ5M2]{Monster Summoning I} table
  • Whatever actors the caster has summoned, add their tokens to the scene
  • Add these tokens to the combat tracker - this is necessary for the autokill effect to work
  • Target the summoned tokens and click the "Summoning I - Duration Autokill" effect
    • The GM can trigger attacks through the attacks/actions on the token

system.description:
[Foundry Note: there are different spell effects; one for the recipient and one for all those within 10 ft of the recipient, so as to differentiate the dependent invisibilities from the source invisibility.

The aura is for visual representation of the AOE, only.  It doesn't convey the invisibility effects as it is possible for a dependent actor to cancel only their invisibility by attacking, etc., while everyone else's invisibility remains intact. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell operates as does the Invisibility spell, but affects all creatures within 10 ft of the recipient at the time the final words of the spell are uttered.

All creatures affected can see each other.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell cannot be cast upon an unwilling subject.

In order to remain invisible, those who were made invisible by virtue of the spell's radius must remain within 10 ft of the creature upon whom the spell is centred.

If the creature upon which the spell was cast makes an attack, the attack will negate the invisibility of all the others.

However, if one of the creatures affected by the spell's radius (not the direct recipient) attacks, the invisibility only of that one creature is negated thereby.  

 

Combat Effects

Invisible opponent: An invisible opponent can only be attacked if the general location is known, and the attack is at –4 to hit.  

Even infravision cannot detect an invisible creature.

If an opponent is invisible to the attacker, he or she cannot be attacked from behind (or from the flank).

Note that more powerful monsters (those with sensitive smell or hearing, or more than six hit dice) will frequently be able to detect invisible opponents; the GM should determine the chance of this according to the creature concerned and the situation.

Powerful magical monsters, or those with more than 11 hit dice, will almost always be able to see invisible creatures normally.

actions.name: Invisibility, 10 ft Radius
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the selected actor (which may be the caster) and click the  "Invisibility Aura - Indefinite (T)" action
    • The aura is to show area, only, because it moves with the caster
    • if any actor with incidental invisibility leaves the aura, that actor's invisibility effect is deleted by the GM
    • if the actor with the aura makes an attack all actors lose their invisibility; delete all invisibility effects on all actors
  • Target all other actors in the aura and click the "Invisibility (Incidental) - Indefinite" action
    • If an actor with incidental invisibility makes an attack the invisibility effect is deleted on that actor only

system.areaOfEffect: All creatures within a 10 ft radius

system.description:
[Foundry Note: the GM will need to track halved number of attacks for slowed creatures manually, but four movement rate effects are provided which halve the common base move rates of 120, 90, 60, and 30, for the GM to selectively apply if applicable. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell acts upon its targets to slow down their movements.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell may be cast upon up to 1 creature/caster level, but all must be within the spell's area of effect at the time of casting.

Haste and Slow automatically cancel each other without any shocks to the systems of those affected.

 

Combat Effects

Any creature affected by a Slow spell will find that it can only move at half normal speed and attack at half its normal rate.

If more than one Slow spell is cast upon the same subject, the effects of the two spells will be cumulative.

  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target chosen actors in the AOE and click the  movement action corresponding to the actor's current movement rate

system.description:
[Foundry Note: if the caster splits up multiple missiles between targets, apply the various damage ranges as missiles; i.e., if a caster has three missiles and sends two to Target A and one to Target B, apply the damage of 2d4+2 to Target A and 1d4+1 to Target B, etc.]

 

General

When this spell is cast, missiles of magical energy dart forth from the caster's fingertips, striking unerringly at his or her intended target(s), even if the target(s) are in melee or are partially concealed.

 

Combat Effects

The missiles inflict [[/roll 1d4+1]] points of damage each.

For every two caster levels beyond first, the caster gains an additional missile; thus, a first-level magic user can cast one missile, a third-level caster may cast 2, a fifth-level caster may cast 3, and so on.

actions.name: Magic Missile
actions.misc:

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target an actor and click the  "Damage (? Missiles)" action corresponding to the number of missiles being sent against that actor
    • The caster can split up their total missiles between multiple targets, but will need to target actors and apply damage sequentially

system.description:
[Foundry Note: while the overall duration of Charm Person is indefinite, a series of effects based on INT score are provided to assist the GM of long-form campaigns in determining when the next saving throw should be made.]

 

General

The powerful enchantment woven by this spell will affect any "person," meaning character races and humanoids (as defined in Chapter V).

 

Saves and Other Impediments

[Elves and half-elves are 90% and 30% resistant to this spell, respectively, and gain a save even if this resistance fails; other listed creature types are entitled to a saving throw (negates).]

The magic user must be able to talk to the charmed creature if he or she is to give it any sort of complex "request."

A caster can have up to a ceiling of one hit die of charmed creatures per character level at any one time.

Charmed creatures are allowed periodic saving throws to break the charm, based on intelligence:

 

Intelligence Saving Throw Frequency
19+ one saving throw/day
18 one saving throw/2 days
17 one saving throw/3 days
15-16 one saving throw/week
13-14 one saving throw/2 weeks
10-12 one saving throw/3 weeks
7-9 one saving throw/month
4-6 one saving throw/2 months
3 or less one saving throw/ 3 months

 

The charm will be broken automatically if the magic user obviously tries to harm the charmed creature.

 

Combat Effects

If the target creature fails a saving throw, it will view the magic user as a trusted friend, interpreting his or her every word in its most positive light.

Charmed creatures will place themselves into moderate danger, including combat, on the caster's behalf, but will not undertake risks beyond those the creature might ordinarily take.

actions.name: Charm Person
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the enemy actor
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done) and trigger a saving throw
  • if the saving throw fails click the applicable  "Charmed ?? INT - Duration (T)" action
