system.description:
General

This spell allows the magic user to decipher a written language (including pictographs), or to understand the speech of another creature.

The reverse of this spell is Indecipherable Languages.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Magical script is not deciphered by this spell.

The spell does not permit the magic user to understand the "speech" of animals; only true, spoken languages can be understood.

The caster gains no ability to speak or write the language, only to comprehend meaning.

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Comprehend Lang - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: A non-saving cast is provided for when the spell is cast upon an object.

The spell doesn't specify the change in strength for creatures without a book STR score, which is most "monstrous" NPCs.  A house rule effect that simply multiplies their damage by increasing percentage based on caster level is also provided, if the GM prefers to handle the spell consequences in that fashion- Ed.]

 

General

This spell causes a creature or object to grow in size and weight. The spell increases:

  •  a creature's size and weight by 20% per caster level (to a maximum increase of 200%)
  • an object's size and weight by 10% per caster level (to a maximum increase of 100%).

The magic user's power limits the volume of material that he or she can enlarge; the mage can affect no more than:

  • 10 cubic ft per level of living matter
  • 5 cubic ft per level of non-living matter

The reverse of this spell is Reduce.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If the spell is cast on an unwilling recipient, a successful saving throw will negate the spell, but willing recipients may choose to forgo the save.

 

Combat Effects

A normal sized person doubled in size will generally have strength of 18, and tripled in size would have strength of 20+.

actions.name: Enlarge
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (If cast on an actor) target an actor and click the  "Enlarge (MU L?-L?) - Duration (T)" action corresponding to the level of the caster
    • If the actor is a non-character monster without a STR score (e.g., a MU summons a goblin and then casts Enlarge on it) then use the   "Enlarged No STR Score - Duration (T)" action instead

actionGroups.name: Enlarge
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: A non-saving cast is provided for when the spell is cast upon an object.

The spell doesn't specify the change in strength for creatures without a book STR score, which is most "monstrous" NPCs.  A house rule effect that simply multiplies their damage by increasing percentage based on caster level is also provided, if the GM prefers to handle the spell consequences in that fashion- Ed.]

system.description:
[Foundry Note: it is a common house rule to grant an additional benefit to the magic user if gaining a "normal" familiar, such as a toad.  This benefit should be minor but useful, such as a vision field similar to the animal's which may be employed at caster discretion.  A GM can determine the exact benefit if they wish to employ the house rule. - Ed.]

 

General

Magic users of higher level often summon familiars to assist them with various tasks. Indeed, a familiar can also be of considerable benefit to a lower level magic user (even increasing others' estimation of his or her power), but the risks inherent in losing a familiar can be daunting to a weaker spell caster.

The caster must maintain his or her casting for as long as necessary ([[/roll 2d12]] hours) until a familiar arrives (or the casting time expires without success).

If a "special familiar" is rolled, the type appearing depends upon the magic user's alignment:

  • Lawful good or Lawful neutral: Brownie
  • Chaotic good, Neutral good, or Neutral: Pseudo-dragon
  • Lawful evil or Neutral evil: Imp
  • Chaotic evil or Chaotic Neutral: Quasit

 

Saves and Other Impediments

To summon a familiar, the magic user must intone the words of the spell over a well-stocked fire source, sprinkling the flames with expensive incense and powders (100 gp in total value).

The spell may be attempted only once per year, and the caster has no control over the type of animal that will respond.

If a special familiar is rolled, it's entitled to a saving throw in order to avoid the effect of the spell.  Normal familiars receive no saving throw.

 

Combat Effects

When it arrives, the familiar is a faithful servant and ally to the caster. Normal familiars have [[/roll 1d3+1]] hit points, are AC 7, and are as intelligent as a lower-than-average human.

When the familiar is within 120 ft of the magic user, the magic user gains additional hit points equal to the familiar's.

However, if the familiar is ever killed, the magic user permanently loses twice the familiar's hit points.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: if you're reading this spell from the context of a 1st level player character casting it, you're not reading it in the context it was used in play in Lake Geneva 1970s campaigns. 

Although the spell is 1st level, it presumes a high level magic user is the caster (i.e., an NPC in town) and most of the restrictions are designed to both necessitate that NPC for low-level parties and thereafter put them incognito for some period after having identified an item - presumably for hire. 

While this interplay may seem foreign to those who've primarily played more-recently written RPGs, this dynamic was all part of intertwining the player characters in the wider urban world it was presumed they were an active participant in (when not delving a gigantic megadungeon, the entrance to level 1 being located approximately 1 hour away from the city) - Ed.]

 

General

This expensive and unreliable spell allows the magic user to discern the magical properties of an item. The magic user must hold or wear the item as intended for use (thereby placing himself at risk of a cursed item).

For every segment of the spell's duration, the magic user has a 15% +5%/caster level of gaining an insight into the nature of the item's enchantment.

Insights include:

  • magical effects (and the corresponding command word)
  • number of charges (plus or minus 25% of the actual number)

The exact bonus (or penalty) of a weapon is not revealed to the player, unless the GM chooses to do so for convenience; the character, of course, would not think of a magic sword as being "+1" or "+3," just as "enchanted" or "powerfully enchanted," and the spell reveals information in these terms.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell must be cast within 1 hour/caster level of the time a magic item first comes near the caster, or the magic user's own aura will have blended too much into the item's aura, contaminating his ability to read it.

Upon casting the spell, the magic user temporarily loses 8 points of constitution, and regains them by resting for one hour per recovered point. 

The material component for the spell is a pearl worth 100 gp.

actions.name: Identify
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • Target the caster and click the  "Identify Con Penalty - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note:

1) there isn't a way to differentiate/automate hurled weapons from bows, etc.  So the lowest base AC automated by the spell is "3" instead of "2".  If a thrown weapon attack (dagger, spear, etc.) is made vs a token having an active shield spell, an additional penalty of -1 should be manually applied to the attack.

2) to mimic the immunity to Magic Missile, an unbundled effect providing immunity to force damage is included. However, the GM should be aware applying this optional effect will protect the caster from all force damage instead of only magic missile damage - the GM will need to manually apply force damage from other sources for the duration of the spell.  Other sources are typically rarer than the ubiquitous magic missile, however.

-Ed.]

[Foundry Beta Note: currently AC effects from spells are inconsistent if the target is wearing anything the system already perceives as armour (this includes such items as bracers of armour).  While the shield spell should work if used by a magic user having no other form of armour, if cast by a MU wearing (for example) bracers of armour +2, the effect may need to be changed from DOWNGRADE 3 or 4 to ADD -4 or -5.  Or the GM can simply ignore any hits that wouldn't be successful against the AC the caster should have. - Ed.]

 

General

By means of this spell, the caster creates an invisible barrier of magical force.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The shield is a frontal defence and grants no benefits against attacks from behind or from the rear flanks.

 

Combat Effects

Magic Missiles cannot penetrate the barrier at all.

The magic user gains an armour class of:

  • AC 2 against any hurled weapon,
  • AC 3 against propelled weapons such as arrows, and
  • AC 4 against all other attacks.

 

All saving throws against frontal attacks (by wands, dragon breath, etc.) are made at +1 during the spell's duration.

actions.name: Shield
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Shield - Duration (C)" action
    • (Optional) also click the "Force Dmg Immunity - Duration (C)" action, but be forewarned this is not Magic Missile-specific, and will make the caster immune to all force damage (the GM can manually apply instead)

system.description:
General

This spell affects a circular area with a 15 ft radius. A number of creatures within this radius (determined by their HD) fall into a deep magical slumber. 

A sleeping creature requires a full round to waken and must be shaken or slapped to bring it to consciousness; mere noise, however loud, will not disturb the enchanted slumber of a sleep spell's victim.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

[Elves and half-elves are 90% and 30% resistant to this spell, respectively, and it doesn't affect many magical or non-biological creatures. However, no saving throws are allowed for more standard creatures without a specific immunity.]

Creatures with hit dice over 4+4 are not affected by the spell.

 

Combat Effects

[Another common houserule is that creatures may only be attacked at 2x rate, but not slain, if a battle is ongoing and the sleeping person isn't otherwise isolated from allies. - Ed.]

Magically sleeping creatures may be killed or tied up at a rate of one per round by a single person, or can be attacked at twice the normal rate with an automatic hit for maximum damage, if the attacker chooses not to kill or bind them.

The number of enemies affected by the spell is a function of their hit dice. If there are creatures of different hit dice in the area, the weaker ones will be affected first.

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.wSpbut6INwOzssXz]{Sleep: # slept (1+ HD to 2 HD)}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.g6ugG4dUUnreneEE]{Sleep: # slept (2+ HD to 3 HD)}

1+ to 2 [[/roll 2d4]]
2+ to 3 [[/roll 1d4]]
3+ to 4 [[/roll 1d2]]
4+1 to 4+4 [[/roll 1d2-1]]

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Roll on the "Sleep: #slept..." table your GM indicates should be used for this combat

system.description:
[Foundry Note: the GM can insert the appropriate number of turns into the unconscious effect after determining the random damage amount. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell enables the magic user to make a written copy of a spell he or she cannot yet cast [including spells otherwise accessible for the caster's level but they've failed a roll to learn], a somewhat dangerous proposition.

If the saving throw [described below] is successful, the magic user may copy the spell, which takes one hour per level of the spell.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The material component is ink costing at least 200 gp.

In order to succeed in this task, the caster must make a saving throw vs spells, with a modifier determined by the difficulty of the spell being transcribed.

  • If the spell is up to one level higher than the magic user can cast, the saving throw is made at +2.
  • If the spell is two levels higher than the magic user can cast, there is no bonus or penalty to the saving throw.
  • If the spell is more than 2 levels higher than the magic user can cast, each additional level adds a -1 penalty.

If the magic user fails this saving throw:

  • the spell is not successfully copied
  • the caster takes [[/roll 1d4]] points of damage for each level of the spell
  • he or she is knocked unconscious for 1 turn per hit point sustained thereby

The damage sustained cannot be healed more quickly than 4 hp per day, even with the assistance of magical healing.

actions.name: Write
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Write - Duration (C)" action
  • The caster should roll a save vrs spells with any appropriate spell level modifier (the saves on the caster's character sheet may be used)
  • If the saving throw fails, target the caster and click the applicable "Damage (Level X Spell Fail)" and also the "Unconscious - Duration (C)" action
    • (Optional) The GM may insert a duration to the unconscious effect on the caster's Details tab after the damage incurred is known

  • If the spell is more than 2 levels higher than the magic user can cast, each additional level adds a -1 penalty.

  • The caster should roll a save vrs spells with any appropriate spell level modifier (the saves on the caster's character sheet may be used)
  • If the saving throw fails, target the caster and click the applicable "Damage (Level X Spell Fail)" and also the "Unconscious - Duration (C)" action
    • (Optional) The GM may insert a duration to the unconscious effect on the caster's Details tab after the damage incurred is known

system.description:
General

When the words of this spell are completed, the recipient and all he or she carries fade from sight, becoming invisible.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell remains in effect until the invisible creature attacks someone, the caster ends the spell, or the magic is dispelled. Note that the spell does not make the recipient any more quiet than normal, nor does it eliminate scents.

The invisible person can see him- or herself, but the caster (unless they are one and the same) cannot.

The spell cannot be cast upon an unwilling subject.

 

Combat Effects

Invisible opponent: An invisible opponent can only be attacked if the general location is known, and the attack is at –4 to hit.  

Even infravision cannot detect an invisible creature.

If an opponent is invisible to the attacker, he or she cannot be attacked from behind (or from the flank).

Note that more powerful monsters (those with sensitive smell or hearing, or more than six hit dice) will frequently be able to detect invisible opponents; the GM should determine the chance of this according to the creature concerned and the situation.

Powerful magical monsters, or those with more than 11 hit dice, will almost always be able to see invisible creatures normally.

actions.name: Invisibility
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the selected actor (which may be the caster) and click the "Invisible - Indefinite (T)" action
    • If the invisible actor makes an attack the invisibility is immediately deleted by the GM

system.description:
General

This spell causes a mass of tough, sticky webs to appear, filling in any open spaces where the webs can be anchored on both sides (floor and ceiling, between walls, etc.), up to the maximum of the spell's area of effect.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Any creature in the area must make a saving throw at a penalty of -2. 

 

Combat Effects

No creature within the area of effect, whether a saving throw is made or not, can cast spells or attack.

Any creature that fails its saving throw has a cumulative 5% chance of suffocating per turn. 

Any creature that makes its save has no chance of suffocating. 

The strands of a web spell are very flammable.  If they are ignited, fire will flash through the entire web, dealing [[/roll 2d4]] points of damage to all creatures within and burning away the webs.

 

[Start of editorial content block:]

[Movement and location of targeted creatures after saving throws are rolled are discussed below.]

 

[If you make your save]

The effect of a successful saving throw depends upon how close the target is to the edge of the area of effect; if the creature is within five ft of the edge of the spell's area of effect, the creature has jumped free and is not affected by the web.

If the creature is not within five ft of the edge and makes its save, that creature will be able to fight its way through the web at twice the normal speed discussed below

  • or at a rate of 1 ft per turn if its strength is less than 13.  

 

[If you fail your save]

Movement is affected by failed saves as follows:

  • Creatures with a strength of less than 13 that fail the saving throw are trapped within the web and cannot move or act at all. 
  • Creatures with a strength of 13-17 are capable of moving through webs at a speed of 1 ft per turn; this is referred to above as "normal speed".
  • A creature with strength 18+ can move through the web at a normal speed rate of 10 ft per turn
  • Creatures such as dragons virtually ignore the webs, breaking through at a normal speed rate of 100 ft per turn or 10 ft per round.

 

WEB MOVEMENT RATES (WHEN JUMPING FREE ISN'T POSSIBLE)

Strength Failed Saving Throw Saving Throw Succeeded
<13 no movement, held fast 1 foot per ten rounds
13-17 1 foot per ten rounds 2 feet per ten rounds
18+ 10 feet per ten rounds 20 feet per ten rounds
Massive 10 feet every round 20 feet every round

 

[Don't forget to roll cumulative suffocation checks every ten rounds for those failing their saving throws.  Many such characters or monsters won't make it to safety unless starting relatively close to the edge of the web (unless they or an ally can burn the webbing). 

Although not specified in the spell, a common house rule is to allow those in the web to be attacked as follows:

  • slain if immobile and reachable with a melee weapon
  • attacked as if stunned (no dex, no shield, +4 to hit) if immobile and missile weapons are required to attack, or, if failing their save with a STR of 13+
  • attacked as rear attacks (no dex, no shield, +2 to hit) if making their save, regardless of weapon used by the attacker. 

- Ed.]

actions.name: Web
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
    • As the AOE can be shaped within reason to the caster's desire, the castshape provides individual 10x10 "blocks" of AOE which may be built into a specific final AOE by re-clicking the action and placing more blocks
  • Target the caster and click  "Web - Duration (C)"
  • Target all actors in the AOE and click  "Save vrs Spell"
  • target actors failing their save and click  "Attack as Stunned - Indefinite (T)"
  • Target actors making their save and click  "Attack as Rear AC - Indefinite (T)"
  • If the web is burned, target all actors still in the AOE and click  "Damage (Burn Web 2d4 Fire)"
    • This removes the web regardless of whether the duration had not yet expired

system.description:
General

With a pointing gesture at the ending of the incantation, the magic user causes a massive explosion of magical fire at the target point.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Creatures making successful saving throws suffer only half the indicated damage.  If they fail this saving throw their carried items are also at risk as described below.

The flames do not create any significant change in air pressure, but the furnace-like heat causes items in the blast not borne by someone making a personal saving throw, to make item saving throws against magical fire or ignite (or, in the case of metals, melt). 

 

Combat Effects

When the magic user casts the spell, a bead of light streaks from his or her pointed finger to the target area, and if it strikes another object directly in its path the fireball will detonate immediately.

The fireball detonates with a low roar, causing [[/roll 1d6]] damage per caster level to all creatures within the area of effect.

The blast fills the entire volume of the spell radius, and if it is cast into an enclosed area smaller than the area of effect the flames will expand from this area until the spell's full volume has been reached.

The volume of a 20 ft radius sphere is approximately 33,500 cubic ft, and there are 1,000 cubic ft in a 10 ft x 10 ft x 10 ft area, so in an area with a 10 ft ceiling the fireball will fill approximately thirty-three 10 ft x 10 ft squares.

Thus, if a fireball explodes in the middle of a corridor 10 ft wide and 10 ft high, the blast will extend a staggering 165 ft in both directions.

It is quite possible, particularly in dungeoneering environments, for the magic user to be caught in the backblast of his or her own Fireball spell.

actions.name: Fireball
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors in the AOE then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger a saving throw (this may already have been done)
  • Click the  "Damage (Fireball)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: there isn't currently a way to effect immunity to only normal missiles while deprecating magical items of these sorts.  An immunity effect to piercing would also negate damage from daggers and short swords, etc. 

The GM may however decline to roll damage for normal missiles while manually applying damage (minus 1) of magical versions of these weapons - Ed.]

 

General

The subject of this spell becomes completely invulnerable to the effects of projectiles.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell's power is not sufficient...to ward off the larger missiles hurled by siege engines such as catapults and ballistae, nor the enchantment of a magic arrow or bolt.

The spell conveys no protection whatsoever against spells, including spells with missile-like qualities such as Fireball or Ray of Enfeeblement.

 

Combat Effects

Any damage caused by weapons this spell is insufficient to ward off (as discussed above) is reduced by 1 hit point per die.

actions.name: Protection From Normal Missiles
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Prot. Normal Missiles- Duration (T)" action

system.description:
[Foundry Note: keep in mind that even though the ice storm is magical, the ice is not.  It doesn't disappear after 1 round, instead melting naturally.  While this is of little consequence to the "hail" version of the spell, the sleet version may have negative consequences, longer, in naturally cool weather vs a hot summer day.  It is up to the GM how long sleet-version penalties last, although blindness due to sleet can likely be cleared away in 1 round, regardless, by actors with freedom of movement. - Ed.]

 

General

The caster may evoke one of two different forms of ice storm with this spell: a hailstorm or a sleet storm.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Neither version of the spell allows for saving throws to avoid the effects.

 

Combat Effects

The hailstorm is a vicious barrage of huge hailstones that pound into a 40 ft x 40 ft area, throwing up bits of shrapnel-like ice fragments as the hail shatters. Any creature within the area suffers [[/roll 3d10]] hit points of damage with no saving throw.

The sleet storm is a maelstrom of frozen rain in an 80 ft x 80 ft area, blinding all creatures in the area of effect and making the footing so slippery that all movement is cut by 50%. There is also a 50% probability that any creature attempting to move while in the sleet storm will slip and fall prone.

actions.name: Ice Storm: Hail
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target all actors in the AOE then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger a saving throw (this may already have been done)
  • Click the  "Damage (3d10 Hail)" action

actions.name: Ice Storm: Sleet
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • If the save fails, click on whichever Blindness action is preferred for use in your GM's campaign and whichever movement action results in a 50% reduction of the target's movement rate

system.description:
General

This spell enables the magic user to cloak him- or herself in the physical shape of another creature, and to continue shape-shifting at will for the length of the spell's duration.

The transformation is of an entirely lesser order than that of polymorph other, incurring no risk of a system shock or of truly becoming the transformed creature.

 

Combat Effects

Changing from one shape to another requires only 30 seconds.  The caster retains his or her own hit points and armour class.

When the caster returns to his or her original form,ending the spell regardless of duration otherwise remaining, he or she will be healed of [[/roll 1d12]] points of any damage inflicted against the polymorphed forms he or she assumed.

The caster can polymorph into forms no smaller than a songbird and no heavier than 2,000 lbs.

Only the movement capabilities of the new form can be used, not its attacks, defences, or other abilities.

The magic user can transform him- or herself into a lion, and run as fast as a lion, but his or her claws will do no more damage than a human's soft fists.

Similarly, if he or she transforms into a dragon, he or she will have the dragon's ability to fly but no breath weapon. As an orc, he or she would be able to use whatever weapons he or she could use in his original shape, but would lack infravision.

actions.name: Polymorph Self
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Poly Self - Duration (T)" action
  • When the caster resumes his form, click "Poly Heal (1d12)"

system.description:
[Foundry Note: the GM may either allow rememorization, or, temporarily increase the spell slots allowed on a character sheet if "overloading" on lower level spells, depending upon how they precisely they wish to account for the benefit. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell enhances the magic user's precision of memory, allowing him or her to retain up to three additional spell levels in his or her mind (3 first level, 1 first and one second level, or 1 third level).

The spell may be used for memorisation, or may be used to hold onto the memory of a spell just cast.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell components are expensive, costing at least 100 gp, and might not be available in rural communities.

actions.misc:

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the "Mnemonic - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
General

Dimension Door is a weak form of teleportation, more controllable than Blink, but severely limited in range.

The teleportation is limited to 30 ft per caster level. Unlike Blink, a Dimension Door spell operates with perfect accuracy, either to a place the caster can see or clearly visualize, or in response to directions (example: "120 ft forward and 30 ft to the right").

If the caster's directions land him or her inside a solid object, he or she is stunned and trapped in the astral plane, held in a sort of suspended animation for eternity unless rescued.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell is subject to a maximum weight limit of 500 lbs of additional weight, with each lb of living matter counting for twice its actual weight.

 

Combat Effects

Recovery from the experience of this form of teleportation is not immediate, although it is quite rapid. The caster cannot act for a period of 6 segments following the transition.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: if the rolled bonus would take an actor with a STR rating over a score of 18, the intent is that all excess would apply to exceptional strength instead of increasing by whole numbers. 

So if cast upon a thief with a STR of 15, and rolling a "5", 3 points would take the thief up to 18 and the remaining 2 points would increase the thief's STR to 18.20, but not increase their STR to a score of 20. 

The GM will need to manually adjust "spillover" if the effect increases STR above 18, as there is no automation to recognize the condition and split the roll.

The 1d6 roll discussed below for non-classed actors is a manual roll by the caster; apply which of the two effects correlates with that roll result. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell increases a person's strength (affecting the same sorts of creatures as Hold Person).

 

REFERENCED TEXT:

Creatures affected by Hold Person include humans, demi-humans and humanoids. Ultimately, it is in the discretion of the GM to decide if a creature is considered a "person" for the purposes of this spell.

 

Combat Effects

The recipient's strength increases by [[/roll 1d6]], and members of the various fighter-type classes gain a roll of [[/roll 1d6+1]].

If the spell is cast upon a monster (such as an orc), the GM is free to rule for convenience that the effect of the spell is to grant +1 to damage, and if the [[/roll 1d6]] roll is a 5 or 6, a +1 to hit as well.

actions.name: Strength
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • Target the actor and click the action below which applies to their nature:
    • If cast on a fighter-type click the "Fighter Type STR Bonus - Duration (T)" action
    • If cast on any other classed actor click the "Non-Fighter STR Bonus - Duration (T)" action
    • If cast on a non-classed actor roll a die and (based on the result) apply either  "Monster Dmg Only - Duration (T)" or  "Monster Dmg+Atk - Duration (T)"

actionGroups.name: Strength
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: if the rolled bonus would take an actor with a STR rating over a score of 18, the intent is that all excess would apply to exceptional strength instead of increasing by whole numbers. 

So if cast upon a thief with a STR of 15, and rolling a "5", 3 points would take the thief up to 18 and the remaining 2 points would increase the thief's STR to 18.20, but not increase their STR to a score of 20. 

The GM will need to manually adjust "spillover" if the effect increases STR above 18, as there is no automation to recognize the condition and split the roll.

The 1d6 roll discussed below for non-classed actors is a manual roll by the caster; apply which of the two effects correlates with that roll result. - Ed.]

General

This evocation produces an invisible disk about three ft across, shaped like a shallow bowl. The disk floats in the air and moves in accordance with the caster's commands.

The disk cannot move faster than 60 ft per round.

A floating disk can carry up to 100 lbs per level of the caster.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

If it is allowed more than 20 ft from the caster it will disappear.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: it is a common house rule to only start the duration of the spell after the monsters appear. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell functions in the same manner as Monster Summoning I.

 

REFERENCED TEXT:

By casting this spell, the magic user conjures...monsters to serve him or her as allies in combat or to perform other services. The monsters appear from thin air within [[/roll 1d4]] rounds of the spell's completed casting.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

For more complex tasks than simple combat, the magic user must somehow have the ability to communicate these more specific commands.

 

Combat Effects

If the caster is in combat, the monsters will fight on his or her behalf, attacking whatever foes he directs, or guarding him or her. 

The GM has the ultimate discretion as to what monsters will appear, but the spell calls [[/roll 1d4]] creatures as determined on the following table:

2 Bugbear

4 Ghoul
5 Lizard, giant
6 Lycanthrope, wererat
7 Ogre
8 Spider, huge
9 Spider, large
10 Weasel, giant

system.description:
General

A Wish spell is the true version of Limited Wish, an extraordinarily potent invocation of eldritch power.

In general, the exact wording of the Wish is carried out regardless of its intent, but the GM will not normally be stringent upon this point unless the wish is an attempt to overreach the spell's power.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

After casting a wish spell, the caster will be weakened considerably, requiring [[/roll 2d4]] days of bed rest. The only exception to this is when the wish is used for transport, healing, or resurrection of the dead. 

In the case of unreasonable wishes, the GM may decide to follow the wording of the spell precisely but pervert the intent, limit the duration of the spell to a very limited time (perhaps mere seconds!) or simply rule that the whole spell fails.

The guideline here is that wishes are granted by someone or something, which may or may not be kindly disposed to the player characters. The more greedy or selfish a wish, the greater the chance that a mischievous or actually evil power will take the opportunity to teach this upstart mortal a lesson.

system.description:
@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.LkUCtqcIYSzHjPAZ]{Potions/Oils/Elixers - Onset Time After Use}

[Foundry Note: the half-drink aspect of potions is handled by giving potions 2 charges, so that half drinks can cost 1 charge and register against the total.  Going this route means the "empty" potion item will need to be manually deleted from inventory once all charges are used, however. 

It is suggested a character benefitting from potions of longevity record the cumulative age reversed, in case it's all reapplied.  Also, there is no "half-drink" for this potion. - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

General

This potion makes the drinker [[/roll 1d12]] years younger. This restored youth is possible not only for natural ageing, but also for ageing from magic or creature effects.

There is some small danger however, since each time a potion of longevity is consumed there is a cumulative 1% probability that all previous age reversals from potions of this type will be negated, raising the character's age to the age he or she would be without the effects of the potions.

It is not possible to drink this potion in increments.
system.dmonlytext:
GPV: 1,000gp

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.rwszf5JfBY1KgHyE]{Potion - Admixture Results}

(Foundry Note: the admixture rule is intended for use with potions that persist concurrently in the body.  It is suggested that potions which apply their benefit and then do not persist (and can't be dispelled) were not intended to be used with that table, as the context of  "permanent" table results makes evident.  However the materials are silent on this point and as such each GM may determine differently - Ed.)

system.description: [Suggested Capacity: 2 cu. ft. or 20 lbs - Ed.]

Allowed Classes

ADFIMPRT

 

Details

Base 2/1 attacks/round only applies to thrown daggers.  Attacks/round for daggers in melee is a base of 1/1.  

Strength damage bonus with missile weapons is restricted to hurled/thrown weapons (axes, hammers, clubs, daggers, darts, javelins and spears).  

 

Range Penalties

Range as Missile To-Hit Penalty
Short (1-10 ft) None
Medium (11-20 ft) -2
Long (21-30 ft) -5
Capacity: 1 (1.0) cu. ft. or 10 lbs

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.LkUCtqcIYSzHjPAZ]{Potions/Oils/Elixers - Onset Time After Use}

[Foundry Note: the half-drink aspect of potions is handled by giving potions 2 charges, so that half drinks can cost 1 charge and register against the total.  Going this route means the "empty" potion item will need to be manually deleted from inventory once all charges are used, however.  - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

General

The person who quaffs this potion, in addition to all items on his or her person, takes on a translucent, gaseous consistency and floats at 30 ft per round. This speed can be different depending on natural wind speed in the environment or due to the effects of wind-altering spells.

This potion must be fully imbibed to have effect.

 

Combat Effects

While in gaseous form, the person affected can flow below doors and other small spaces not sealed airtight.

Although magical lightening and fire do the gaseous form full damage, while in gaseous form the imbiber is otherwise impervious to other attacks.

However, double the normal damage is inflicted by a whirlwind.

@UUID[RollTable.LkUCtqcIYSzHjPAZ]{Potions/Oils/Elixers - Onset Time After Use}

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

General

When this potion is quaffed, the drinker is bestowed with the spell-like ability of Invisibility.

This potion can be consumed in 1/8 increments, in which case the invisibility granted lasts [[/roll 1d4+2]] turns per dose.

 

REFERENCED TEXT: 

The recipient and all he or she carries fade from sight, becoming invisible. The invisible person can see him- or herself.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

Any combat action removes the invisibility granted, as does dispelling the magic, such that a new dose must be consumed.

Note that the spell does not make the recipient any more quiet than normal, nor does it eliminate scents.

 

Combat Effects

Invisible opponent: An invisible opponent can only be attacked if the general location is known, and the attack is at –4 to hit.  

Even infravision cannot detect an invisible creature.

If an opponent is invisible to the attacker, he or she cannot be attacked from behind (or from the flank).

Note that more powerful monsters (those with sensitive smell or hearing, or more than six hit dice) will frequently be able to detect invisible opponents; the GM should determine the chance of this according to the creature concerned and the situation.

Powerful magical monsters, or those with more than 11 hit dice, will almost always be able to see invisible creatures normally.

General

This potion is aptly named, for it convinces the drinker that the potion is of another type. If more than one person tastes this potion, there is a 90% chance they all will believe the potion to be of the same type.

For example, a potion of clairaudience might convince the drinker there are sounds in the distance that do not truly exist.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: there's a passive effect upgrading bonuses to +6 when facing fire using/dwelling creatures.  These are additive, so an upgrade to a total of "+6" will show as a series of "+3" adjustments. - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

AFPRT

 

Details

The frost brand is normally +3, granting a +6 bonus against any creature using fire as its attack (e.g. red dragons) or dwelling in fire such as fire elementals.

This weapon grants special defence against fire; treat the wielder as if he or she were wearing a ring of fire resistance.

The cold-based magic of the blade also has a 50% chance of extinguishing fire for a 10 ft radius, including magical fires such as a Wall of Fire but not fire based attacks such as hell hound breath attacks or Fireballs.

Note: this blade does not shed light when drawn unless the ambient temperature is below freezing.

 

REFERENCED TEXT: 

This ring grants immunity to normal fires such as torches or flaming oil.

Very hot fires such as molten lava or hell hound breath inflict only 1 hp of damage per segment, and even then only if the wearer is directly touching or targeted by such.  [This type of damage requires manual administration by the GM. - Ed.]

Exceptionally hot fires such as red dragon breath or fireballs inflict -2 points of damage per die (but always inflict at least 1 point of damage) and saving throws are rolled at +4.

The following rule of thumb should assist with determining damage reduction of fire types not explicitly mentioned above:

  • "very hot" fires inflict up to 24 points of maximum damage
  • "exceptionally hot" fires cause 25 or more points of maximum damage.
system.dmonlytext:
GPV: 8,000gp

[Foundry Note: most fire attacks with a potential of less than 24 damage only last 1 segment ("instantaneous"), and so, all such instantaneous "very hot" damage should be manually reversed by the DM except for 1 point ]

system.description: Auto-created for Frost Brand Sword, Long

[Foundry Note: unlike the illusionist version, which is a full radius and so is automated, the cone-shaped AOE of the MU version of this spell doesn't lend itself to an aura to show an AOE that moves with the caster. 

This makes using an automated detect invisibility effect impossible, as there's no way currently to make it only work in the beam-shaped area of effect that a magic user has.  

However, if there is ever a question of the AOE the caster can see at a given moment, the castshape effect can be superimposed on the map again temporarily to show the visual area without setting it down on the scene (right-click to dismiss).  Then the GM can ping where an invisible creature is for the MU player and provide a verbal description.

A "Sixth Sense (Scrying)" skill is provided on spellcasting actors having high levels, which is also modified by high INT.  Should this spell's use be attempted on any actor having this skill, a passive check to notice the scrying should be made every round. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell allows the caster to see that which is invisible or hidden, and also to perceive the astral and aethereal planes.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell's sight is limited to the stated area of effect of 10 ft/caster level.

actions.name: Detect Invisibility
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Target the caster and click the "Detect Invisibility - Duration (C)" action

actionGroups.name: Detect Invisibility
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: unlike the illusionist version, which is a full radius and so is automated, the cone-shaped AOE of the MU version of this spell doesn't lend itself to an aura to show an AOE that moves with the caster. 

This makes using an automated detect invisibility effect impossible, as there's no way currently to make it only work in the beam-shaped area of effect that a magic user has.  

However, if there is ever a question of the AOE the caster can see at a given moment, the castshape effect can be superimposed on the map again temporarily to show the visual area without setting it down on the scene (right-click to dismiss).  Then the GM can ping where an invisible creature is for the MU player and provide a verbal description.

A "Sixth Sense (Scrying)" skill is provided on spellcasting actors having high levels, which is also modified by high INT.  Should this spell's use be attempted on any actor having this skill, a passive check to notice the scrying should be made every round. - Ed.]

system.description:
General

This spell causes creatures to behave strangely and unpredictably.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

A certain number of creatures in the spell's area of effect must make a saving throw each round in order to avoid becoming confused.

The base number of creatures is [[/roll 2d4]], but additional creatures may be affected; if the druid's caster level is higher than the HD of the strongest opponent, the difference is the number of additional creatures that must make saving throws.

This spell is extremely powerful; all saving throws are made with a penalty of -2.

Note: a creature that meanders away is not entitled to further saving throws, but will be freed from the spell's effects after taking a full turn of movement (at normal speed) away from the caster.

 

Combat Effects

Creatures that fail their saving throws (check each round) act randomly in accordance with the following table:

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.zB42jaGBcBpo3CA6]{Confusion Effect}

 

d% Action
01-10 Attacks the druid or his or her allies
11-20 Acts normally
21-50 Babbles incoherently
51-70 Meanders away from caster for a full turn
71-00 Attacks nearest creature

actions.name: Confusion
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
  • Determine how many enemy actors can be targeted (see spell description)
  • Target these actors then cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge and trigger the save vs magic at -2
  • Click the  "Confusion - Duration (T)" action to apply it to those actors who failed their saving throws
  • Roll on the @UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.zB42jaGBcBpo3CA6]{Confusion Effect} for each confused actor to determine their course of action that round

system.description:
Appraising: This proficiency is highly
useful for thieves, as it allows characters to
estimate the value and authenticity of
antiques, art objects, jewelry, cut gem-
stones, or other crafted items they find
(although the DM can exclude those items
too exotic or rare to be well known). The
character must have the item in hand to
examine. A successful proficiency check
(rolled by the DM) enables the character to
estimate the value of the item to the nearest
100 or 1,000 gp and to identify fakes. On a
failed check, the character cannot estimate a
price at all. On a roll of 20, the character
wildly misreads the value of the item,
always to the detriment of the character.

Etiquette: This proficiency gives the char-
acter a basic understanding of the proper
forms of behavior and address required in
many different situations, especially those
involving nobility and persons of rank.
Thus, the character will know the correct
title to use when addressing a duke, the
proper steps of ceremony to greet visiting
diplomats, gestures to avoid in the presence
of dwarves, etc. For extremely unusual
occurrences, a proficiency check must be
made for the character to know the proper
etiquette for the situation (an imperial visit,
for example, is a sufficiently rare event).
However, having the character know
what is correct and actually do what is cor-
rect are two different matters. The encoun-
ters must still be role-played by the
character. Knowledge of etiquette does not
give the character protection from a gaffe or
faux pas; many people who know the cor-
rect thing still manage to do the exact oppo-
site.

Musical Instrument: The character can
play a specific musical instrument. An addi-
tional instrument can be added for every
extra slot devoted to this proficiency. The
character plays quite well, and no proficien-
cy check is normally required. The DM may
direct the character to make a proficiency
check in what he feels are extraordinary cir-
cumstances.

ReadinglWriting: The character can read
and write a modern language he can speak,
provided there is someone available to teach
the character (another PC, a hireling, or an
NPC).This proficiency does not enable the
character to learn ancient languages (see
Languages, Ancient).

Riding, Land-Based: Those skilled in land
riding are proficient in the art of riding and
handling horses or other types of ground
mounts. When the proficiency slot is filled,
the character must declare which type of
mount he is proficient in. Possibilities
include griffons, unicorns, dire wolves, and
virtually any creatures used as mounts by
humans, demihumans, or humanoids.
A character with riding proficiency can
perform all of the following feats. Some of
them are automatic, while others require a
proficiency check for success.
The character can vault onto a saddle
whenever the horse or other mount is stand-
ing still, even when the character is wearing
armor. This does not require a proficiency
check. The character must make a check,
however, if he wishes to get the mount mov-
ing during the same round in which he lands
in its saddle. He must also make a proficien-
cy check if he attempts to vault onto the sad-
dle of a moving mount. Failure indicates
that the character falls to the ground-
presumably quite embarrassed.
The character can urge the mount to
jump tall obstacles or leap across gaps. No
check is required if the obstacle is less than
three feet tall or the gap is less than 12 feet
wide. If the character wants to roll a profi-
ciency check, the mount can be urged to
leap obstacles up to seven feet high, or jump
across gaps up to 30 feet wide. Success
means that the mount has made the jump.
Failure indicates that it balks, and the char-
acter must make another proficiency check
to see whether he retains his seat or falls to
the ground.
* The character can spur his steed on to
great speeds, adding 6 feet per round to the
animal's movement rate for up to four
turns. This requires a proficiency check
each turn to see if the mount can be pushed
this hard. If the initial check fails, no further
attempts may be made, but the mount can
move normally. If the second or subsequent
check fails, the mount immediately slows to
a walk, and the character must dismount
and lead the animal for a turn. In any event,
after four turns of racing, the steed must be
walked by its dismounted rider for one turn.
* The character can guide his mount with
hisknees, enabling him to use weapons that
two hands (such as bows and two-
EzG swords) while mounted. This feat
does not require a proficiency check unless
the character takes damage while so riding.
In this case, a check is required and failure
means that the character falls to the ground
and sustains an additional ld6 points of
damage.
* The character can drop down and hang
alongside the steed, using it as a shield
against attack. The character cannot make
an attack or wear armor while performing
this feat. The character’s Armor Class is
lowered by 6 while this maneuver is per-
forme+ Any attacks that would have struck
the character’s normal Armor Class are con-
sidered to have struck the mount instead.
No proficiency check is required.
* The character can leap from the back of
his steed to the ground and make a melee
attack against any character or creature
within 10 feet. The player must roll a suc-
cessful proficiency check with a -4 penalty
to succeed. On a failed roll, the character
fails to land on his feet, falls clumsily to the
grpund, and suffers Id3 points of damage.

Rope Use: This proficiency enables a
character to accomplish amazing feats with
rope. A character with rope use proficiency
is familiar with all sorts of knots and can tie
knots that slip, hold tightly, slide slowly, or
loosen with a quick tug. If the character’s
hands are bound and held with a knot, he
can roll a proficiency check (with a -6 pen-
alty) to escape the bonds.
This character gains a +2 bonus to all
attacks made with a lasso. The character
also receives a +10 percent bonus to all
climbing checks made while he is using a
rope, including attempts to belay (secure the
end of a climbing rope) companions.

Spellcraft: Although this proficiency does
not grant the character any spellcasting
powers, it does give him familiarity-with the
different forms and rites of spellcasting. If
he observes and overhears someone who is
casting a spell, or if he examines the material
components used, he can attempt to identify
the spell being cast. A proficiency check
must be rolIed to make a correct idendifica-
tion. Wizard specialists spin a +3 bonus to
the check when attempting to identify magic
of their own school. Note that since the
spellcaster must be observed until the my
instant of casting, the spellcraft proficiency
does not grant an advantage against combat
spells. The proficiency is quite useful, how-
ever, for identifying spells that would other-
wise have no visible effect.
Those talented in this proficiency also
have a chance (equal to 1/2 of their
proficiency check) of recognizing magical) or
magically endowed constructs for what
they are.

Smlmming: A character with swimming
proficiency knows how to swim and can-
move according to the rules given in the
Swimming section (page 120). Those with-
out this proficiency carinot swim. They can
hold their breath and float, but they cannot
move themselves about in the water.

Tightrope Walking: The character can
attempt to walk narrow ropes or beams
with greater than normal chances of suc-
cess. He can negotiate any narrow surface
not angled up or down greater than 45
degrees. Each round the character can walk
60 feet. One proficiency check is made eve-
ry 60 feet (or part thereof), with failure indi-
cating a fall. The check is made with a -10
penalty to the ability score if the surface is
1 inch or less in width (a rope), a -5 pen-
alty if 2 inches to 6 inches wide, and
unmodified if 7-12 inches wide.

Wider than one foot requires no check
for proficient characters under normal cir-
cumstances. Every additional proficiency
spnr on tightrope walking reduces these
penalties by 1. Use of a balancing rod reduc-
es the penalties by 2. Winds or vibrations in
Wline increases the penalty by 2 to 6.
Tlte character can attempt to fight while
on a tightrope, but he suffers a - 5 penalty
to his attack roll and must roll a successful
proficiency check at the beginning of each
round to avoid falling off. Since the charac-
ter cannot maneuver, he gains no adjust-
ments to his Armor Class for Dexterity. If he
is struck while on the rope, he must roll an
immdiate proficiency check to retain his
balance.

Tumbling: The character is practiced in
all manner of acrobatics-dive, roils, som-
ersaults, handstands, flips, ctc. Tumbling
can only be performed while burdened with
light encumbrance or less. Aside from enter-
taining, the character with tumbling profi-
ciency can improve his Armor Class by 4
against attacks directed solely at him in any
round of combat, provided he has the initia-
tive and foregoes attacks that round.
When in unarmed combat he can improve
his attack roll by 2.
On a successful proficiency check, he suf-
fers only one-half the normal damage from
falls of 60 feet or less and none from falls of
10 feet or less. Falls from greater heights
result in normal damage.

Riding, Airborne: The character is trained
in handling a flying mount. The particular
creature must be chosen when the proficien-
cy is chosen. Additional proficiency slots can
be used to learn how to handle other types of
mounts. Unlike land-based riding, a charac-
ter must have this proficiency (or ride with
someone who does) to handle a flying
mount. In addition, a proficient character
can do the following:
* Leap onto the saddle of the creature
(when it is standing on the ground) and spur
it airborne as a single action. This requires
no proficiency check.
* Leap from the back of the mount and
drop 10 feet to the ground or onto the back
of another mount (land-based or flying).
Those with only light encumbrance can
drop to the ground without a proficiency
check. In all other situations, a proficiency
check is required. A failed roll means the
character takes normal falling damage (for
falling flat on his face) or misses his target
(perhaps taking large amounts of damage as
a result). A character who is dropping to the
ground can attempt an immediate melee
attack, if his proficiency check is made with
a - 4 penalty to the ability roll. Failure has
the consequences given above.
Spur his mount to greater speeds on a
successful check, adding ld4 to the move-
ment rate of the mount. This speed can be
maintained for four consecutive rounds. If
the check fails, an attempt can be made
again the next round. If two checks fail, no
attempt can be made for a full turn. After
the rounds of increased speed, its movement
drops to 2/3 its normal rate and its Maneu-
verability Class (see Glossary) becomes one
class worse. These conditions last until the
mount lands and is allowed to rest for at
least one hour.
* The rider can guide the mount with his
knees and feet, keeping his hands free. A
proficiency check is made only after the
character suffers damage. If the check is
failed, the character is knocked from the
saddle. A second check is allowed to see if
the character manages to catch himself (thus
hanging from the side by one hand or in
some equally perilous position). If this fails,
the rider falls. Of course a rider can strap
himself into the saddle, although this could
be a disadvantage if his mount is slain and
plummets toward the ground.

Jarl Grugnur,


Our master grows impatient. You will accelerate your raids against the human settlements and prepare your warriors to join my army when summoned. The cloud giants report increased vigilance among the human patrols - leave no survivors who might warn of our activities.
Send tribute and confirmation of your loyalty. The ogre magi oversee our alliance on behalf of our master - their instructions are to be followed without question.


King Snurre Iron Belly
Lord of the Fire Giants


𐎀𐎓𐎐 𐎁𐎒𐎓𐎘𐎀, 𐎃𐎒𐎅𐎄𐎀 𐎅𐎒 𐎄𐎘 𐎀𐎓𐎗 𐎄𐎐𐎀!

𐎀𐎓𐎗 𐎅𐎘𐎒𐎉𐎘𐎅 𐎀𐎒 𐎂𐎘𐎐𐎀!
𐎀𐎒𐎗 𐎂𐎘𐎄𐎄 𐎀𐎗𐎉𐎀𐎐𐎀!
𐎂𐎘𐎄 𐎂𐎀𐎀𐎓𐎘 𐎂𐎀𐎒𐎀𐎄,
𐎀𐎒𐎗 𐎂𐎒𐎂𐎅 𐎂𐎀𐎄𐎒𐎗!
𐎁𐎒𐎓𐎘𐎀 𐎀𐎄 𐎀𐎒𐎗 𐎂𐎘𐎉𐎒𐎄𐎀𐎉𐎂𐎘𐎄 𐎉𐎂 𐎀𐎄𐎀!

𐎅𐎘𐎒 𐎉𐎀𐎂𐎘𐎄𐎒 𐎂𐎘𐎄𐎄 𐎉𐎂𐎀𐎒𐎀𐎄𐎂𐎘𐎄!
𐎀𐎒𐎗 𐎂𐎀𐎉𐎂𐎘𐎄 𐎂𐎘𐎐𐎘𐎀!
𐎉𐎂𐎘𐎀𐎀𐎒𐎂𐎘𐎄 𐎂𐎀𐎉𐎂𐎘𐎄𐎀𐎐𐎘𐎀!

𐎀𐎀𐎀𐎀𐎀 𐎂𐎀𐎉𐎘𐎐𐎘𐎀!!!

system.description:
To my loyal servants, the Lords of the Oni-kind:


The adventurers who interfered at Tsojcanth now pose an even greater threat. My servant Obmi reports they wield a powerful artifact - an ornate golden lanthorn of ancient design that he observed during the attack on the Steading. This can only be Daoud's Wondrous Lanthorn from my half-sister's collection. There may be other artifacts they've claimed that remain unknown to us.
These relics, combined with their continued interference, mark them as our most dangerous opponents. More troubling still is how they seem shielded from my divinations. When I seek their movements, time itself seems to distort. My warnings to our forces arrive too late or become forgotten.
You are to personally oversee the defenses of all giant strongholds. The frost giants under Jarl Grugnur must be prepared for these intruders immediately. The cloud fortress must maintain vigilance, and King Snurre must accelerate preparations at the hall of the fire giants.
If you encounter these meddlers, observe and report what artifacts they possess. The golden lanthorn must be recovered, and any other items they carry from Tsojcanth's depths.


Let none question that this is the will of Iuz the Old, Tyrant of the North.
By my Hand and Word, this 20th day of Fireseek, 569 CY"



"Gorukh na’shath! Lords ov Oni-kin!

Tassh’ven rokad Tsojcanth—ni’shaku vlok mograth! Obmi’ka shurgruk! Ishka-thran ashak vlun’tor—LANTHORN! Gol’drath, ezh’tak thrul! Daru’ka Daoud’shath! Half-Sister’shath!

Vlok thash! Meddler’shath glom’ka thrak! Ush’vur mak’kloth—sha’su div’nath klor! Time-vrath break’sa! Uzgor’shath blind’tor! Gorukh’ash!

YOU, Oni’thran! Hold strong! Frost’Jarl Grugnur! Readi’ka! Cloud’shrath! Watch! Snurre’zash! Burn, break, crash! Now!

Meddler’ka? See! Tell! LANTHORN—TAKE! Tsojcanth’ka trath—TAKE!

NA’GOR! Will ov IUZ-THRAN! TYRANT ov NORTH!

Gorukh! Uzgor’sha! Fireseek 20th! Year 569!"

system.description:
Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

A made but otherwise plain leather haversack with two side pouches and brass hardware.

Each side pouch functions as a Bag of Holding and both will hold up to either 20 cubic ft of material or 20 lbs in weight.

The main part of the haversack can hold up to 80 cubic ft of material or 80 lbs of weight.

No matter how much material is placed into the handy haversack it will never weigh more than 5 lbs. When the user reaches into the pack for a specific item, that item will always be on top.

[Foundry Note: an aura has been added, so as to be visible and persistant while a caster moves, to represent the ring effect.

A separate shape effect is given in 20 ft blocks for a caster to detail on a map (in 20 ft chunks) the size of the spell if casting it as a wall. - Ed.]

 

General

A magic user's Wall of Fire does base damage of [[/roll 2d6+8]] hit points. If the wall is configured as a ring its radius will be 34 ft. In all other respects, the spell resembles the druidic spell Wall of Fire.

 

REFERENCED TEXT:

A blazing inferno of flame in the shape of a wall. One side of the conflagration emits the searing heat one would expect, but the other side emits merely a gentle warmth.

The wall persists for as long as the magic user concentrates upon it.  [Foundry Note: - concentration precludes movement or any other action.  If the druid desires to move they must stop concentrating to do so. - Ed.]

If the magic user does not choose to maintain concentration, it remains for 8 rounds. 

The druid may evoke a Wall of Fire in one of two shapes.

Straight wall:

  • up to one 20 ft square per caster level arranged as desired
  • a wall is stationary

Ring:

  • radius of up to 34 ft (caster in centre)
  • 20 ft high
  • A ring moves with the caster

 

Saves and Other Impediments

No saving throws are allowed to avoid or reduce taken from the wall.

 

Combat Effects

Passing through the flames inflicts [[/roll 2d6+8]] hit points. Additionally:

  • Creatures as far as 10 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 2d4]] hit points of damage.
  • Creatures between 10 and 20 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 1d4]] points of damage.

Undead creatures suffer worse from the power of this magic, taking twice the ordinary damage the wall would inflict.

actions.name: Wall of Fire
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) to visualize a ring casting, target the caster and click the  "Ring Aura - (C)" action, which has no mechanical function but provides a visual indication of the AOE which moves with the caster
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize a wall casting's area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
    • As the AOE can be shaped within reason to the caster's desire, the castshape provides individual 20x20 "blocks" of AOE which may be built into a specific final AOE by re-clicking the action and placing more blocks
  • If the caster stops concentrating (to move or attack, for example) target the caster and click the  "WOF Post-Concentration - Duration (C)" action to start the finite duration
  • If an undead actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the undead actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • if the undead actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 4d4 Fire)" action
    • If the undead actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Undead Wall Touch" action
  • If any other actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 1d4 Fire)" action
    • if the actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • If the actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Wall Touch" action

Combat Effects

Passing through the flames inflicts [[/roll 2d6+8]] hit points. Additionally:

  • Creatures as far as 10 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 2d4]] hit points of damage.
  • Creatures between 10 and 20 ft from the hot side incur [[/roll 1d4]] points of damage.

Undead creatures suffer worse from the power of this magic, taking twice the ordinary damage the wall would inflict.

actions.name: Wall of Fire
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • (Optional) to visualize a ring casting, target the caster and click the  "Ring Aura - (C)" action, which has no mechanical function but provides a visual indication of the AOE which moves with the caster
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize a wall casting's area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)
    • As the AOE can be shaped within reason to the caster's desire, the castshape provides individual 20x20 "blocks" of AOE which may be built into a specific final AOE by re-clicking the action and placing more blocks
  • If the caster stops concentrating (to move or attack, for example) target the caster and click the  "WOF Post-Concentration - Duration (C)" action to start the finite duration
  • If an undead actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the undead actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • if the undead actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 4d4 Fire)" action
    • If the undead actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Undead Wall Touch" action
  • If any other actor interacts with the ring/wall, apply damage as follows:
    • if the actor is between 11 and 20 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 1d4 Fire)" action
    • if the actor is between 1 and 10 feet from the wall, target it and click the  "Damage (Proximity 2d4 Fire)" action
    • If the actor contacts the wall, target it and click the  "Wall Touch" action

system.description:
General

The teleport spell permits the caster to transport him- or herself, and any additional weight he or she can carry, instantly from one place to another.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The magic user must be familiar with the destination (see below).  But there is no effective range to the spell, although it does not permit travel to other planes.

 

Combat Effects

To see how well the teleportation works, the player will roll d% and consult the table below.

 

Familiarity On Target Off Target Similar Area Mishap
Very familiar 01-97 98-99 100 -
Studied carefully 01-94 95-97 98-99 100
Seen casually 01-88 89-94 95-96 97-100
Viewed once 01-76 77-88 89-92 93-100
False destination ([[/roll 1d20+80]]) - 81-92 93-100

 

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.R05j6xfyZW5owLOI]{Teleport - Very Familiar}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.8ZEZmu2qCnddevQG]{Teleport - Studied Carefully}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.qMr2qMvdWwuwdGeP]{Teleport - Seen Casually}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.C0Zzi3d94lqdThFg]{Teleport - Viewed Once}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.ORQIFb1vHtdoudZ8]{Teleport - False Destination}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.n4DBQlGu7V5Z9hRL]{Teleport - Off Target}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.H5P4syppJAm5aJa4]{Teleport - Similar Area}

 

Refer to the following information for definitions of the terms contained in table:

Familiarity :

"Very familiar" is a place where the caster has been very often and feels at home.

"Studied carefully" is a place the caster knows well, either because he or she can currently see it, has been there often, or has used other means (such as scrying) to study the place for at least one hour.

"Seen casually" is a place that the caster has seen more than once but with which he or she is not very familiar.

"Viewed once" is a place that the caster has seen once, possibly using magic.

"False destination" is a place that does not truly exist, or if the caster is teleporting to an otherwise familiar location that no longer exists as such, or has been so completely altered as to no longer be considered "familiar."

When travelling to a false destination, the player rolls [[/roll 1d20+80]] on the table rather than rolling d%, as there is no real destination.

On Target: The caster appears in the correct location.

Off Target: The caster appears safely, a random distance away from the destination in a random direction.

Distance off target is [[/roll 1d10]]x[[/roll 1d10]]% of the distance that was to be travelled.

The direction off target is determined randomly by rolling 1d8 to determine the compass point.

Similar Area: The caster winds up in an area that is visually or thematically similar (depending on how the caster identified it while casting) to the target area.

Generally, the caster will appear in the closest similar place within range. If no such area exists within the spell's range, the spell simply fails.

It is possible (25% chance) that this result will indicate that the correct location has been reached but that the caster and party will arrive too high, falling 1d% ft unless there is means to arrest the fall.

If the party arrives too high and the result would entomb them in a solid surface, they die instantly.

Mishap: The caster and anyone else teleporting with him or her arrive beneath the destination point, causing instant death if the area is solid.

system.description:
Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

A character studying this book a minimum of 48 hours over the course of a single week and diligently performing the mental exercises contained within its pages will gain 1 point of permanent increase to his or her intelligence score.

The tome vanishes forever after 1 use.
system.dmonlytext:
GPV: 27,500gp

 

Note on Books (All)

All magical books, tomes, volumes etc. appear on cursory inspection as non-magical volumes of arcana.

The only spells that will aid in distinguishing one type of magical tome from another are identify and wish. All other spells or powers are useless in this regard.

Two wishes are required to determine the exact nature of any book, the first revealing only the general classes or characteristics most affected (but not whether for good or ill!).

Most books will immediately disappear after being read, although a GM may of course decide to have a detrimental work stay with a character until a remove curse is employed.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: a "Sixth Sense (Scrying)" skill is provided on spellcasting actors having high levels, which is also modified by high INT.  Should this spell's use be attempted on any actor having this skill, a passive check to notice the scrying should be made every round. - Ed.]

 

General

This spell allows the caster to overhear the surface thoughts of any thinking being in the spell's radial area of effect.

The caster need not be able to see the creature whose thoughts he is reading; the spell can be used to listen beyond a closed door.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The spell cannot penetrate more than two ft of stone or more than two inches of any metal, and it is foiled by even a thin sheet of lead.

system.description:
General

The mirror image spell creates [[/roll 1d4]] phantasmal images of the magic user, all mirroring his or her actions. The spell's 6ft radius also becomes slightly blurred to sight, like the reflection of a slightly distorted mirror.

At the end of the spell's duration, any remaining images fade from sight.

The combination of these two magical phenomena makes it impossible to distinguish the images from the caster without aid of a magical nature, such as True Seeing.

 

Combat Effects

When an opponent makes a successful hit against one of the images, the image breaks up and disappears (the others remain). If an opponent attempts to attack a magic user obscured by this spell, it is randomly determined whether the to-hit roll is directed toward the person or one of the images.

actions.name: Mirror Image
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • Target the caster and click the  "Mirror Image - Duration (C)" action

system.description:
General

Dispel Magic has a base chance of 50% to permanently negate magic - both the magical properties of potions and the ongoing effects of certain spells.

All spell effects and relevant items within the stated area of effect are subject to dispelling.

The spell will automatically negate the caster's own spells if it is used for this purpose or if the caster has previously cast a spell into the same area.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

With respect to each potion, casting, or ongoing spell effect, the base chance of successful dispelling is increased 5% for every level by which the caster's level exceeds the caster level of the potion, the casting, or the spell effect.

The base chance is conversely reduced by 2% per level of difference if the caster is lower level than the caster of the magic to be dispelled.

 

Combat Effects

Any spells in the process of being cast in the spell's area of effect will be lost, and any ongoing spell effects (such as invisibility) will be dispelled, presuming the adjusted % chance(s) discussed above are resolved in the favor of the caster of Dispel Magic.

Permanent magical items are not disenchanted, i.e., ruined permanently, by the spell when used as an area effect - with the exception of potions which are treated as 12th level for purposes of resolution.

However, even a permanently enchanted item must make a saving throw vs spells (as if being rolled by its carrier) or become non-operational for one round.  A Dispel Magic cast for this purpose is entirely consumed in the attempt and doesn't effect other magic in the area as previously described.  Legendary magical items are an exception to even this possibility.

actions.name: Dispel Magic
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done).
  • (Optional) Use the  castshape action to visualize the area of effect (you can delete AOE templates if the Templates menu is active)

system.description:
General

This spell has the same effect as the clerical spell Hold Person: to immobilise foes and render them helpless. However, the magic user's version of the spell is somewhat more flexible in terms of the caster's options.

A Hold Person spell completely immobilises up to four man-sized or smaller persons for the spell's duration. 

Creatures affected by this spell would include humans, demi-humans and humanoids. Ultimately, it is in the discretion of the GM to decide if a creature is considered a "person" for the purposes of this spell.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The magic user decides how many of his or her foes he or she will target with the spell:

  • if there is only one target, the saving throw is made at -3
  • if two targets, each makes the saving throw at -1
  • if three or four targets, each makes the saving throw with no penalty

If a magic item or spell operates to partially negate the effects of paralysis, failure on the saving throw will have the effect of a Slow spell rather than completely immobilising the target.

 

Combat Effects

[Another common houserule is that creatures may only be attacked at 2x rate, but not slain, if a battle is ongoing and the incapacitated person isn't otherwise isolated from allies. - Ed.]

Persons held by this spell may be killed or bound at a rate of one per round, or, if the attacker chooses, may be attacked at twice the normal rate with an automatic hit, for maximum damage.

actions.name: Hold Person (1 Target)
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target the enemy actor
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done)
  • if the saving throw fails click the  "Held - Duration (T)" action

actions.misc:

  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (these may already have been done)

system.description:
[Foundry Note: while the overall duration of Charm Monster is indefinite, an effect lasting one week is provided to assist the GM of long-form campaigns in determining when the next saving throw should be made.]

 

General

This spell operates as Charm Person does, but can affect any living creature; possibly more than one, depending on the monsters' level value.

 

REFERENCED TEXT:

Saves and Other Impediments

[Elves and half-elves are 90% and 30% resistant to this spell, respectively, and gain a save even if this resistance fails; other listed creature types are entitled to a saving throw (only).

A GM may wish to allow a max roll on the table below to supersede the general rule for this spell of hit die and caster level, as it's possible for the table to provide results exceeding a caster's level. - Ed.]

The magic user must be able to talk to the charmed creature if he or she is to give it any sort of complex "request."

A caster can have up to a ceiling of one hit die of charmed creatures per character level at any one time. 

Charmed creatures are allowed periodic saving throws to break the charm, based on level value; See the chart below:

 

Level value of monsters Number affected Chance/ week to break enchantment
Level 1 [[/roll 2d4]] 5%
Level 2 [[/roll 1d4]] 10%
Level 3 [[/roll 1d2]] 15%
Level 4 1 25%
Level 5 1 35%
Level 6 1 45%
Level 7 1 60%
Level 8 1 75%
Level 9+ 1 90%

 

The charm will be broken automatically if the magic user obviously tries to harm the charmed creature.

 

Combat Effects

If the target creature fails a saving throw, it will view the magic user as a trusted friend, interpreting his or her every word in its most positive light.

Charmed creatures will place themselves into moderate danger, including combat, on the caster's behalf, but will not undertake risks beyond those the creature might ordinarily take.

actions.name: Charm Monster
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions

  • Target an actor
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done) and trigger a saving throw
  • If the save fails click the "Charmed - One Week (T)" action
